		<item>
		<title>It&#039;s Not About the Paper, Senator!</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/04/30/it-isnt-about-the-paper-senator/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 01 May 2009 02:44:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Journalism]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="journalism"><![CDATA[Journalism]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=110</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_114" align="aligncenter" width="720" caption="Astronaut Leroy Chiao, Miles O&#039;Brien and David Waters in the midst of a five-hour webcast covering the launch of STS-119. "]<img class="size-full wp-image-114" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/04/sfn_2.jpg" alt="sfn_2" width="720" height="440" />[/caption]
<p style="text-align:left;">Blogger Bill Salvin really gets it. He understands what is happening in the world of journalism - and he realizes it is not all bad. The free market can and should decide on its own how it uses its free press. Politicians don't belong here - muddying the clear waters of our First Ammendment</p>

<blockquote><a href="http://signalbridge.blogspot.com/2009/04/future-of-journalism-part-ii.html">View From The Bridge: The Future of Journalism, Part II</a>.

My advice to Senator Kerry (not that he’s asking) is to let the journalists and entrepreneurs figure this out. Miles O’Brien was laid off from anchoring and reporting on CNN, but he’s back anchoring and reporting in this new environment (and doing really well!). Just as people figured out how to make their newspapers relevant with the advent of radio, and radio reinvented itself when television came on the scene, the media will figure this out. We know that people want news. We know that people will figure out ways to make money delivering it.

Congress can’t help with this.  Freedom of the Press includes the freedom to fail.</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Hear hear, Miles. Every time I hear someone propose that the big newspapers go 'not-for-profit,' I think of all the publications in America that are money losers for certain political interests. Because the deep pockets that back them need not worry about section 501(c)(3) of the tax code, they can attempt to influence politics in whatever way they like, although they too are effectively not-for-profit. Neutering the free speech abilities of some newspapers to make economic survival a little easier seems like the wrong path.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[A very smart man that lived around 230 years ago once said he would rather have a free press than a standing army. This man was Thomas Jefferson (ever hear of him, Mr. Kerry?). Bill Salvin is on the right path with this article. The government that governs best, governs least.]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
		<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
		<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
				<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>897</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Jeff McMahon]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>jeff@planetobispo.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.trueslant.com/jeffmcmahon</wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>172.20.1.252</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2009-05-01 13:56:43</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-05-01 17:56:43</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[The thought of government involvement in the press makes me queasy, too, but let's not forget that the free market is also a threat to the free press. Should the free market determine what we publish, for example?

Salvin asks, "How will we trust that an editorial written to endorse a candidate isn’t compromised because Uncle Sam dropped a big bag of cash to the publisher?"

And to that I'd ask, "How do we trust that an editorial written to endorse a candidate isn’t compromised because an advertiser dropped a big bag of cash to the publisher?"

Sometimes we don't trust, but to the extent that we do, we're trusting journalists to resist outside influences, including government and business.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<item>
		<title>(Legal) Blood Doping at Everest</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/04/30/time-for-some-legal-blood-doping-at-everest/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 01 May 2009 03:57:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Climbing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="climbing"><![CDATA[Climbing]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="everest"><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Everest Base Camp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="everest-base-camp"><![CDATA[Everest Base Camp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Facebook]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="facebook"><![CDATA[Facebook]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mount-everest"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mountaineering]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mountaineering"><![CDATA[Mountaineering]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Sherpa people]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="sherpa-people"><![CDATA[Sherpa people]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Skyper]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="skyper"><![CDATA[Skyper]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Twitter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="twitter"><![CDATA[Twitter]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=121</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[COLUMBUS, Ohio (April 30 @ 11:30pm EDT) - Just got off the Skype with Astronaut Scott Prazynski and his Media Sherpa Kieth Cowing at Everest Base Camp. Great conversation. Got a bunch of questions in from Twitter and Facebook. Feel free to leave questions you might have below. Scott is hoping to summit on May 9 - the full moon. Mother Nature may throw a momkey wrench into those plans however. We won't have video from Scott for a few days as he is heading into thicker air - to do some legal blood-doping at a village a few thousand feet below Base Camp.

Scott's blog is <a href="http://onorbit.com/everest">here.</a> The maps (politcal, satellite and topographic) showing his tracks up and down the mountains - courtesy of the SPOT satellite tracking device - are found <a href="http://share.findmespot.com/shared/faces/viewspots.jsp?glId=00BOo9XoItxROPePqKqiqhskZpoy7Z8LF">here</a>.
<p style="text-align:left;">Among the questions I posed on behalf of the Interweb Nation:
<strong>Neel Patel</strong>: How long does it take to acclimate to a new atmospheric elevation so that the climbers don't develop hypoxia and hyperventilation.
<strong>Terry Kathleen Kirchhoff:</strong> What is the average cost to participate in a successful climb for an American?
<strong>Dale Andersen:</strong> Will Scott be measuring barometric pressure at the summit or if he will log it during the climb. It would make for an interesting plot.
<strong>Andrea Mikulin Winters Kalbfleisch:</strong> Which part of the climb is the hardest...base camp 2 to camp 3 for example, the summit, the climb down, the Hillary Steps?
<strong>Brian Okeefe:</strong> What is he doing to clean up the mountain?
</p><p style="text-align:left;"><strong>Sabine Hope:</strong> How are his lungs feeling?<strong></strong></p>
<p style="text-align:left;"><strong>Sasha Winderbaum Dds: </strong>What are the temps like ?</p>
<p style="text-align:left;"><strong> fox_in_space: </strong>what's the power source for Your equipment there? How much low temperature affects Your gear?</p>
<p style="text-align:left;"></p>
<p style="text-align:left;">[kaltura-widget wid="y5yubva3i0" width="410" height="364" addpermission="2" editpermission="2" /]</p>
<p style="text-align:center;"></p>

<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=f18d959a-21f3-4697-a931-d0df71f5e378" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Meet the Sherpas!</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/01/meet-the-sherpas/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 02 May 2009 03:44:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Asia]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="asia"><![CDATA[Asia]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Climb]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="climb"><![CDATA[Climb]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="everest"><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Everest Base Camp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="everest-base-camp"><![CDATA[Everest Base Camp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mount-everest"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mountaineering]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mountaineering"><![CDATA[Mountaineering]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Nepal]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nepal"><![CDATA[Nepal]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Recreation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="recreation"><![CDATA[Recreation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Sherpa people]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="sherpa-people"><![CDATA[Sherpa people]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=145</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_159" align="alignright" width="225" caption="Tenzing Norgay in May 1953."]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/tenzing_norgay.gif"><img class="size-full wp-image-159" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/tenzing_norgay.gif" alt="Tenzing Norgay in May 1953." width="225" height="200" /></a>[/caption]
<p style="text-align:left;">COLUMBUS,  Ohio - Astronaut Scott Parazynski checked in from Everest Base Camp at 11:15pm EDT - 9am Saturday morning at Everest. This was a surprise as he told me 24 hours ago that he was going to hike down into thicker air to do some blood doping for the big push to the top. But on further reflection, he decided not to go. Word is some climbers got the trots while there - and it is overrun with lowly trekkers  - who are not aiming for the summit. A real mountaineer cannot be seen with such a crowd, can he /she? This gave us a serendipitous chance to meet Scott's Sherpa Deanuru - who has summited Everest no less than ten times. Scott's video Sherpa Keith Cowing also had a few words to say about these amazing, resilient guides (his has topped off 11 times). So what's the secret to being a good Sherpa you wonder? I asked (of course)...</p>
<p style="text-align:center;">[kaltura-widget wid="6cqr0oti9p" width="410" height="364" addpermission="3" editpermission="3" align="center" /]</p>
<p style="text-align:center;"></p>
<p style="text-align:center;"></p>
<p style="text-align:center;"></p>

		<item>
		<title>&#039;Please No One be Under There...&#039;</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/04/please-no-one-be-under-there/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 04 May 2009 10:23:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Environment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="environment"><![CDATA[Environment]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="everest"><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Everest Base Camp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="everest-base-camp"><![CDATA[Everest Base Camp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Kids and Teens]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="kids-and-teens"><![CDATA[Kids and Teens]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mount-everest"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Ozone layer]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="ozone-layer"><![CDATA[Ozone layer]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[School Time]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="school-time"><![CDATA[School Time]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Skype]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="skype"><![CDATA[Skype]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Ultraviolet]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="ultraviolet"><![CDATA[Ultraviolet]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=162</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[NEW YORK  (May 3) - Astronaut and soon to be Everest Summiteer (we hope) Scott Parazynski checked in for a Skype vidchat with me a short time ago. This five-time shuttle flier and veteran spacewalker admitted he has some butterflies as the summit date appraoches. Given the weather conditions areound Everest now, his team leader Eric Simonsen is expecting to make a bid to top off sometime between May 11 and 14 - give or take.

Scott's sidekick in this Mutt and Jeff team is Keith Cowing. I asked him about some of the scientific experiments Scott will be taking to the summit. One of the big questions astrobiologists have is how life does in conditions where there is little protection from the atmosphere's ozone layer. Four billion years ago, in the pre-Sunblockian era, living things managed OK even though they got blasted by unfiltered UV rays.

I also asked Scott about this scary avalanche footage that he and Keith captured earlier Sunday:
<p style="text-align:center;">[kaltura-widget wid="xdzvfl87fg" width="410" height="364" addpermission="0" editpermission="0" align="center" /]</p>

He and everyone else in Base Camp were convinced they were watching someone's demise. They all got on their radios and started frantically calling comrades to ensure everyone was accounted for. Fortunately, they were.
<p style="text-align:center;"></p>

You can read Scott's blog <a href="http://onorbit.com/everest">here</a>. And you can follow his tracks in real time with position reports from his SPOT satellite tracker - located <a href="http://share.findmespot.com/shared/faces/viewspots.jsp?glId=00BOo9XoItxROPePqKqiqhskZpoy7Z8LF">here</a>. Below is my Skype vidchat:
<p style="text-align:center;">[kaltura-widget wid="5u0ooxfqs8" width="410" height="364" addpermission="0" editpermission="0" align="center" /]</p>
<p style="text-align:center;"></p>

<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=ab6b0cc1-c9ad-49f4-9151-a60185ef0555" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Man versus Mountain</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/06/man-versus-mountain/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 06 May 2009 10:44:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Climbing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="climbing"><![CDATA[Climbing]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="everest"><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Khumbu Icefall]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="khumbu-icefall"><![CDATA[Khumbu Icefall]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mount-everest"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[mountaineer]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mountaineer"><![CDATA[mountaineer]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Nepal]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nepal"><![CDATA[Nepal]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=177</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align:left;">Astronaut Scott Parazynski is learning his bid to summit Everest can be a lot like a shuttle launch - heavily dependent on the whims of weather. The window for "topping off" - as they say in the mountaineering biz - is now "moving to the right" - as they say in the rocket biz. For Scott, this means more time to (literally) cool his heels at Everest Base Camp. In my latest Skype vidchat with him, he allowed how it can be at times tedious - and lonely for a dad and husband.
[kaltura-widget wid="cot451dap4" width="410" height="364" addpermission="0" editpermission="0" align="center" /]</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

		<item>
		<title>On his way to the Top of the World</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/06/on-his-way-to-the-top-of-the-world/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 07 May 2009 02:13:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Astronaut]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="astronaut"><![CDATA[Astronaut]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Climb]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="climb"><![CDATA[Climb]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mount-everest"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[mountaineer]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mountaineer"><![CDATA[mountaineer]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mountaineering]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Recreation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Scott E. Parazynski]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="scott-e-parazynski"><![CDATA[Scott E. Parazynski]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Sherpa]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="sherpa"><![CDATA[Sherpa]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=185</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Astronaut Scott Parazynski and the <a href="http://www.mountainguides.com/everest-south09.shtml">IMG climbing team</a> have left Everest Base Camp and are now at <a href="http://www.nepalvista.com/travel/efacts.html">Camp 2 </a>- on their way to the summit of the tallest mountain on the planet. If he succeeds in "topping off," he will become the first person to fly in space who has reached such lofty heights as a mountaineer. Scott's sidekick (and media sherpa) Keith Cowing remains at Base Camp - listening to the radios. He will keep us posted on Scott's progress. Tense, tough days ahead for the climbers - and for those of us rooting for them. This is dangerous business. You can read Scott's blog <a href="http://onorbit.com/everest">here.</a> and you can follow his tracks to the top of the world at the SPOT Adventures site <a href="http://www.spotadventures.com/">here</a>.
<p style="text-align:center;">[kaltura-widget wid="i5fxy7ko38" width="410" height="364" addpermission="0" editpermission="0" align="center" /]</p>
<p style="text-align:left;">After Scott left Base Camp, those who remained saw a huge avalanche - a reminder of the dangers. Still shots and an early report from Keith Cowing are <a href="http://www.onorbit.com/node/994">here</a>.</p>
<p style="text-align:center;">[kaltura-widget wid="5cgg55t28w" width="410" height="364" addpermission="0" editpermission="0" align="center" /]</p>

<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=d794e84e-d3f5-43a0-9971-6c5f5ccea2b7" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align:center;">[kaltura-widget wid="5pq2bbd17g" width="410" height="364" addpermission="0" editpermission="0" align="center" /]</p>
<p style="text-align:left;">Astronaut Scott Parazynski still making his way to the summit. It was a tragic day at Base Camp however - as a Sherpa guide died in a huge avalanche. I spoke with Keith Cowing this morning EDT - evening on Everest.</p>

<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=871672d5-8d53-4e0a-ad26-c66187c34f80" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Back at Base Camp - Bad Weather, Bad Luck</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/09/back-at-base-camp-bad-weather-bad-luck/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 09 May 2009 10:49:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Astronaut]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="astronaut"><![CDATA[Astronaut]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Avalanche]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="avalanche"><![CDATA[Avalanche]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Climb]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="climb"><![CDATA[Climb]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Climbing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="climbing"><![CDATA[Climbing]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="everest"><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Everest Base Camp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="everest-base-camp"><![CDATA[Everest Base Camp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mount-everest"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mountaineering]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mountaineering"><![CDATA[Mountaineering]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Recreation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="recreation"><![CDATA[Recreation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Scott E. Parazynski]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="scott-e-parazynski"><![CDATA[Scott E. Parazynski]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Scott Parazynski]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="scott-parazynski"><![CDATA[Scott Parazynski]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Sherpa]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="sherpa"><![CDATA[Sherpa]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=211</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Astronaut Scott Parazynski and the IMG climbing team are back now at Everest Base Camp after bad weather and some bad luck prompted them to turn back from their first summit bid of this climbing season.They will take some time to rest and head to lower, thicker air and will not likely see the summit anytime before May 20.  Scott checked in from the EBC comm tent - speaking with me about the weather, the loss of a sherpa guide in an avalanche - and how this is a lot like a shuttle main engine abort on the launch pad...

Scott writes this in his blog:
<blockquote>I had been in great spirits up through the Icefall, simply pleased with my time and conditioning --- but by the time I got up to Camp II, my climbing partner had had to abort his summit bid, and a fatal avalanche had let loose from the West Shoulder of Everest. Chilling. I want nothing more than to top out on Everest in the next few days, and never pass through the Icefall again…</blockquote>
Scott's full blog posting is <a href="http://onorbit.com/everest">here</a> and you can follow his tracks with the help of the SPOT Satellite Messenger <a href="http://www.spotadventures.com/">here</a>.
<p style="text-align:center;">[kaltura-widget wid="tujxv3rz28" width="410" height="364" addpermission="0" editpermission="0" align="center" /]</p>

<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=ef9e29c7-f82b-41ce-bb7c-79a96629b427" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Heavy Snow...Uncertain Future on Everest &#124; On Orbit</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/12/heavy-snowuncertain-future-on-everest-on-orbit/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 May 2009 03:54:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Astronaut]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="astronaut"><![CDATA[Astronaut]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="everest"><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="everest"><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Kieth Cowing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="kieth-cowing"><![CDATA[Kieth Cowing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mountaineering]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mountaineering"><![CDATA[Mountaineering]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Scott Parazynski]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="scott-parazynski"><![CDATA[Scott Parazynski]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=221</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.onorbit.com/node/1015">Heavy Snow...Uncertain Future on Everest | On Orbit</a>.

Astronaut Scott Parazynski and his Media Sherpa Keith Cowing remain in Pheriche, Nepal - where the air is (relatively) thicker, the toilet facilities are (relatively) more comfortable - and the internet access is blocked by mountains. The weather and the news from the mountain is not good. So far, no one has reached the summit - and the monsoon season is but a few weeks away.
<blockquote>A thick wet snow is falling here in Pheriche on Day 52 of the expedition, and uncertainty exists as to when we can easily return to EBC, when the weather might lift to allow teams to recommence their summit bids, and when we might get our chance… Snow up high means fixed lines will likely be covered, as will have our bootprints from multiple prior forays up the route. All 20+ climbing teams will be poised to go at the first hint of promising weather, which might result in crowding and bottlenecks. Meanwhile, the end of May and the approach of the monsoon season is less than 3 weeks away.</blockquote>
You can follow Scott's tracks vie the SPOT Satellite Messenger at <a href="http://www.spotadventures.com/">www.SPOTAdventures.com</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>From Sully...to Sullied</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/13/from-sullyto-sullied/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 May 2009 14:38:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Add new tag]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="add-new-tag"><![CDATA[Add new tag]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Airline]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="airline"><![CDATA[Airline]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Airline Deregulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="airline-deregulation"><![CDATA[Airline Deregulation]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="aviation"><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="aviation"><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Buffalo]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="buffalo"><![CDATA[Buffalo]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Cockpit voice recorder]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="cockpit-voice-recorder"><![CDATA[Cockpit voice recorder]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Colgan]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="colgan"><![CDATA[Colgan]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Continental]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="continental"><![CDATA[Continental]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[FAA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="faa"><![CDATA[FAA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Federal Aviation Administration]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="federal-aviation-administration"><![CDATA[Federal Aviation Administration]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[First officer]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="first-officer"><![CDATA[First officer]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Flight 3407]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="flight-3407"><![CDATA[Flight 3407]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Jimmy Carter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="jimmy-carter"><![CDATA[Jimmy Carter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[National Transportation Safety Board]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="national-transportation-safety-board"><![CDATA[National Transportation Safety Board]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NTSB]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="ntsb"><![CDATA[NTSB]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Undercarriage]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="undercarriage"><![CDATA[Undercarriage]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=229</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-232" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/05/airlinederegulationact.gif" alt="airlinederegulationact" width="365" height="251" />When the wreckage of Colgan/Continental Flight 3407 was still smoldering near Buffalo, I <a href="http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/02/16/the-groundhog-day-accident/">blogged</a> that aircraft icing was a likely potential cause of the crash. Turns out, it was just icing on the cake - a cake that has been in the oven for more than thirty years now.

It was October 24, 1978 when President Jimmy Carter signed the Airline Deregulation Act. There were a lot of good reasons then to remove the tie-downs and chalks on the airline industry. The Civil Aeronautics Board had become egregiously bureaucratic and good people with good business plans were stymied by government rules and inaction.

So why not allow the free market to prevail? Wouldn’t competition be a win-win for the American people and the airlines? Thirty years later, it is hard to find a winner – unless your only metric is your ability to fly roundtrip coast-to-coast for $200.

Well I have news for you: your mother was right…you get what you pay for. And tragically, Flight 3407 is what we ordered up back in 1978.

A “Sully” was not at the controls that dark and misty night. If he were, I would not be writing this now because it would have been just another routine arrival on a cold, misty night at BUF. There was no reason this airplane should have crashed – and yet it makes perfect since when you understand how stressed the system has become.

You will hear all kinds of spin and posterior-covering as the NTSB continues its hearings, but here it is in black and white for you: the flight crew was overworked, overtired, underpaid, undertrained and inexperienced. Period.

Some rules were broken. Before the flight Captain Marvin Renslow slept in the crew room at Newark after commuting from Tampa. First Officer Rebecca Shaw flew through the night from her home in Seattle and was up all day before signing in for her final trip. And the crew did not maintain a “sterile cockpit” (meaning no chit-chat) as they descended below 10,000 feet.

Otherwise, they - and the airline - apparently met the minimum FAA requirements.

But the those minimums still allowed:
<ul>
	<li>A captain to flunk no less than five flight exams and still hold the “left seat”.</li>
	<li>Those long commutes between a pilot’s home and base.</li>
	<li>The airline to pay pilots paltry wages.</li>
	<li>Only 8 hours of rest time (from wheel-stop to sign-in for next flight).</li>
</ul>
Reading the <a href="http://www.ntsb.gov/dockets/aviation/dca09ma027/418693.pdf">transcript</a> of the CVR  is a gut-wrenching experience for me. I can only imagine what it must be like for someone who lost a loved one that February night.

The crew was shockingly disengaged and unappreciative of the ice that had built up on their craft – and had minimal experience flying safely though it.

Said Shaw: “I've never seen icing conditions. I've never deiced. I've never seen any— I've never experienced any of that. I don't want to have to experience that and make those kinds of calls. You know I'dve freaked out. I'dve have like seen this much ice and thought oh my gosh we were going to crash.”

They also never even made mention of their rapidly degrading airspeed once they deployed the landing gear as they  began the final stage of the approach.

And then, when the airplane started demanding their attention  (in most urgent terms) with an automatic “stick-pusher” designed to remind the pilot to push on the yoke, get the nose down and build up some airspeed or face imminent aerodynamic stall, they overruled it – pulling back hard – sealing the outcome. The <a href="http://www.ntsb.gov/events/2009/buffalo-ny/animationdescription.htm">3-D animation </a>is also hard to watch.

But it really wasn’t their fault at all. They were set up to fail by a system that operates on the ratty edge of disaster every day.

This is a systemic problem, people. And it needs to be fixed now. Should the airlines be re-regulated? Well, for one thing, they are already the most regulated “unregulated” industry I can think of. But, no, there has to be a way to keep the free market alive, level the playing field for all competitors, keep barriers to entry low and yet preserve the kind of safety margin that is embodied in the "Sully" generation.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

								<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>903</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[ladybird53]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>ladybird53@sbcglobal.net</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>172.20.1.252</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2009-05-13 11:49:31</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-05-13 15:49:31</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[This nails what aviation professionals have known for years. The free market wrecking crew has sown an amazing crop of regulatory agencies packed with people who really don't believe in govt regulation, and destroyed a great industry - along with a few lives. The cost of doing business? American has been conned bigtime in the 'government bad - free market good" fairy tale. It's time we woke up and started acting like adults and really taking care of business.
As a followup, I recommend: "Wrecking Crew" by WSJ reporter Thomas Frank, for a better look at what free market hath wrot.
www.mavenandmeddler.com]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
		<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
		<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
				<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>904</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Lewis DVorkin]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>dvorkin@publicpostinc.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url>http://</wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>172.20.1.252</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2009-05-13 12:20:28</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-05-13 16:20:28</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Miles,
I know this is crazy, but for the past few years I just hate flying in bad weather. When the plane I'm in stops on the tarmac for de-icing, well, I just hope for the best. I never felt like this. But my trust in the entire system is pretty much non-existent right now. The financial pressures, the governmental issues, my perceived loss of qualified pilots, the training of mechanics... I just don't know how all that can sync up to give me faith that it will all work out.]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>

		<wp:comment_author_email>vivbernstein@gmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url>http://</wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>172.20.1.252</wp:comment_author_IP>

		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-05-13 20:36:32</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[If making sure pilots are trained to fly the planes they're flying is re-regulation, then I'm all for it. How many people have to die before the airline industry decides to put safety ahead of cost efficiency?]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
		<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
		<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
				<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>906</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[rocky]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>alanwprice@yahoo.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url>http://</wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>172.20.1.252</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2009-05-13 19:19:47</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-05-13 23:19:47</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Miles,

The truth among veteran airline pilots is that deregulation opened Pandora's box.  It has taken 30 years for us to reap what we sowed but reap it we have.  As Sully said before Congress, the pay, working conditions, and experience levels have all slid drastically south.  I retired (early) 5 years ago after a 30-year airline career, mainly to avoid losing what I could salvage from my retirement plan as I watched my airline enter chapter 11.  Sad state of affairs.  It took us 75 years to create this aviation system and one day to destroy it, the day deregulation was approved.

Regards,

Rocky]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
		<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
		<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
				<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>907</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[jondc9]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>jondc9@aol.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>172.20.1.252</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2009-05-13 19:25:57</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-05-13 23:25:57</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[First let me identify myself as a pilot.  I am medically grounded now, but in my 34 years in aviation I have held or currently hold the following credentials:

Private Pilot Single Engine Land
Instrument rating
Commercial Pilot Single Engine Land
commercial Pilot Multi Engine Land
Certified flight instructor
Certified Instrument Instructor
Certified Multi-Engine Instructor
Airline Transport PIlot (this is the PHD of flying) Multi Engine Land

I've flown for 3 small regional airlines.  Taught all sorts of students how to fly, some now airline pilots.  I've flown bank checks (mail) in rotten little planes in terrible weather. My last assignment was as captain for a major airline flying the 737.

I agree with the majority of Miles' blog.  It boils down to this.  This crash was avoidable if the MONEY had been spent to properly train the crew, and for the crew to afford a lifestyle that any of you would consider standard.  How many of you would sleep in the office building you work in?  Could you live in the New York metropolitan area on $16,000 a year?  Could you live in Sioux Falls, South Dakota on $16,000 a year?

I came up flying the hard way as we pilots call it.  I spent years teaching others how to fly and during that time I learned more about flying than I have ever had to use while keeping safe those passengers aboard my airline.

When I was young, I read "The Spirit of St. Louis" by the great Charles A. Lindbergh.  Even he mentioned he never learned more about flying than when he taught someone else and could see the myriad of mistakes that can happen.

One of the finest books on the subject of flying is "Stick and Rudder" by noted test pilot Wolfgang Langweische.  One of the huge fallacies of flying is that you pull back on the ''stick" (or control wheel) and you go up.  Indeed the control is called the ELEVATOR...so what would someone think?  But if you pull back or UP too much the plane will fall out of the sky and kill you.  The entire book is an explanation of what pilots call THE ANGLE OF ATTACK.  That magical way of air moving across the wing to produce lift, which is the way a plane is held up in the sky.

Colgan crashed because the pilots didn't understand the fundamentals of stall recovery.  Some huge error in their training, or in fatigue compromised judgment, or something as yet fully understood caused this crash.  It might have been prevented by reading "Stick and Rudder".

BUT, as Miles has said, this crash was 30 years in the making.  It costs a lot of money to fly right.  But the airline industry no longer pays a lot of money to pilots, or for their training.  And the public still complains about high fares, baggage fees and the like.

I disagree with Miles about the cure. I do support Re-Regulating the airlines.  The new Civil Aeronautics Board could be headed by someone who thinks like me.  You do things right and then you charge what you have to, to pay for doing it right and a reasonable profit (say ten percent).  You also make sure that the plane is well maintained, the seats comfortably large, and do you know what an airline could compete on?  SERVICE.  Not how cheap something could be done.

After this crash, shouldn't we wake up?  Are you aware that pilots for Federal Express and UPS, who fly boxes around for a living, are PAID MORE than pilots at American Airlines or United Airlines?  Think about that!  And the pay at a Colgan or something similar is much, much worse.

Aren't you, the traveling public, worth a few extra bucks?]]></wp:comment_content>

The NTSB routinely releases the CVR transcripts. Families almost always find the transcripts disturbing.  For that reason the NTSB never releases the actual recordings -- at least it never releases the recordings voluntarily. It takes a court order to get the actual recordings, and those orders issue only under exceptional circumstances.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<wp:comment_id>914</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[flite]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>flite@san.rr.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>172.20.1.252</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2009-05-15 22:34:05</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-05-16 02:34:05</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA["... overworked, overtired, underpaid, undertrained and inexperienced."
Thank you Miles O'Brian for bringing the industry's dirty little secrets to the forefront!

I entered the industry as a pilot for a major airline within a year of airline deregulation.  Over the ensuing years I have witnessed the industry's decline in most all areas.  The corners cut across the board post-deregulation – including safety – are forever fueled by thin margins, persistent cutthroat competition, and forever cost-cutting managements.

It has fostered a downward spiral, especially for those on the bottom.    Indeed, the sweatshop wages and hour, and superficial training  for those on the lower,  but still  professional tier are almost criminal.

For years I (and many other pilots) fought against the many deleterious effects of deregulation upon the airline pilot profession; effects that also directly affect and threaten a mostly unknowing, flying public.  But I had little success against the massive, economic interests of those in both the private and public sectors.

12 years ago I wrote a letter to the Wall Street Journal  ( http://www.flitetime.net/wsj_ltr.pdf ) concerning pilot fatigue and lax regulations.  Nothing has changed since.  In fact I believe the risks have increased.

Although retired, I am still in tune with the industry.   And I do advise my family on certain flights, and certain airlines they are to avoid.]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
		<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
		<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>

				<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>915</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[adamblack]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>goldhill1953@yahoo.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url>http://</wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>172.20.1.252</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2009-06-03 15:00:16</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-06-03 19:00:16</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Miles,

You and all the other journalists missed the most important thing about the Colgan crash at Buffalo.  When the Captain called for flaps 15 the copilot only put out 10 degrees of flaps.  Then when the stall began the First Officer raised the flaps without being commanded to do so by the Captain.  The Captain did not use the correct procedure of lowering the nose to recover from the stall but when the FO raised the flaps, the plane was doomed to crashing as it did soon after.  The FO also never monitored the airspeed during the approach as the Monitoring Pilot is suppose to do.
At one point during the stall the plane was at about 960 feet above the ground and with 133 kts of airspeed but the wing flaps were incorrectly retracted.  If the flaps were at 15 degrees at that point, as they were called for by the Captain, a stall recovery would have been most likely possible.  The NTSB testimony from a Bombardier Engineer makes it clear that retracting the flaps during a stall is the worst thing you can do.
Please try to get some good sources who can explain all of this to you.]]></wp:comment_content>

			</item>
		<item>
		<title>Lidle Lawsuit is Frivolous</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/14/lidle-lawsuit-is-frivolous/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 14 May 2009 10:32:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Add new tag]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="add-new-tag"><![CDATA[Add new tag]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="aviation"><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Cirrus Design]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="cirrus-design"><![CDATA[Cirrus Design]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Cory Lidle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="cory-lidle"><![CDATA[Cory Lidle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Manhattan]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="manhattan"><![CDATA[Manhattan]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NTSB]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="ntsb"><![CDATA[NTSB]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Plane Crash]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="plane-crash"><![CDATA[Plane Crash]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=253</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div class="zemanta-img">

[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Image via Wikipedia"]<a href="http://commons.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Belaire_Condominium%2C_12_October_2006.jpg"><img src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/05/300px-belaire_condominium2c_12_october_2006.jpg" alt="Belaire Condominium, 12 October 2006, after be..." width="300" /></a>[/caption]

</div>
<blockquote><a href="http://www.nydailynews.com/news/2009/05/14/2009-05-14_new_evidence_in_lidle_plane_crash.html">New evidence in Lidle plane crash</a>.

Lidle's wife, Melanie, is suing plane maker <a title="Cirrus Design Corporation" href="http://www.nydailynews.com/topics/Cirrus+Design+Corporation">Cirrus Design Corp.</a> in <a title="Manhattan Supreme Court" href="http://www.nydailynews.com/topics/Manhattan+Supreme+Court">Manhattan Federal Court</a>, claiming a breakdown in the plane's controls caused the deaths of her husband and flight instructor <a title="Tyler Stanger" href="http://www.nydailynews.com/topics/Tyler+Stanger">Tyler Stanger</a>. Stanger's family has joined in the suit.</blockquote>
I have tremendous sympathy for the families left behind in the wake of Cory Lidle's crash into a Manhattan high rise in October 2006. But lawsuits like this are precisely what is wrong with our judicial system.

A low time pilot, with a relatively inexperienced, locally unfamiliar instructor depart on a marginal VFR day with a low ceiling for a sightseeing tour up a narrow, dead-end corridor for small airplanes. They fly up the middle of that corridor at about 500 feet and make a steep left turn downwind. The plane stalls (or comes close) and when they roll out, a building is staring them in the face.

This accident had nothing to do with the airplane - it was the human beings inside. The NTSB concluded the cause was "the pilots' inadequate planning, judgment, and airmanship in the performance of a 180º turn maneuver inside of a limited turning space."

But in our litigious society, the facts don't matter very much. One way or another we all pay for this. And the lawyers are the only real winners. Sad eplilogue to a tragic story.
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=bc5b6c90-999d-4dfd-9cc1-79650fe511e3" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

								<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>916</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[mikedanko]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>mdanko@dankolaw.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>172.20.1.252</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2009-05-14 12:42:56</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-05-14 16:42:56</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Miles-

The problem with NTSB investigations is that they have a built-in conflict of interest.  That's because the NTSB allows the aircraft manufacturers to participate in the investigations but excludes the families and the families' experts. Because of this conflict, the NTSB's final conclusions almost always favor the manufacturer.

Fortunately, victims who are exluded from the NTSB's investigations don't need to accept the NTSB's conclusions.  They can bring a lawsuit and, once they have the power of subpoena, they can conduct their own investigations.  It's not a matter of being "frivolous", it's a matter of basic fairness.

There is a known problem with the Cirrus ailerons jamming at full deflection.  After this accident, Cirrus published a number of service bulletins in an attempt to correct the problem. I'm not saying that the aileron problem caused the Lidle crash.  But the families are entitled to use the power of subpoena that comes with filing a lawsuit to investigate what happened.  They don't have to simply accept the NTSB's conclusion -- a conclusion the NTSB reached after listening to Cirrus' experts behind closed doors.]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Well said Miles, and spot on.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<item>
		<title>Astronaut at Everest Base Camp - Looking Up!</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/14/astronaut-at-everest-base-camp-looking-up/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 14 May 2009 15:07:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="everest"><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Everest Base Camp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="everest-base-camp"><![CDATA[Everest Base Camp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mount-everest"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mountaineering]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mountaineering"><![CDATA[Mountaineering]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Nepal]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nepal"><![CDATA[Nepal]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Recreation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="recreation"><![CDATA[Recreation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Scott E. Parazynski]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="scott-e-parazynski"><![CDATA[Scott E. Parazynski]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Skype]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="skype"><![CDATA[Skype]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[United States]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="united-states"><![CDATA[United States]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=261</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-269" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/img_3964.jpg" alt="img_3964" width="155" />

Just heard from Astronaut Scott Parazynski. After a few days in thicker air - sleeping on a bed in a a hotel, he is back at Everest base Camp. I will have a Skype chat with him tonight at 11pm EDT. Below is a portion of the blog entry I just posted for him at <a href="http://onorbit.com/everest">http://onorbit.com/everest.</a> You can follow Scott's tracks at <a href="http://www.spotadventures.com/">http://SPOTAdventures.com</a>
<blockquote>The weather appears to be cooperating, as we had a beautiful, cloud-free morning --- and a typical EBC afternoon with clouds and light snow. Some teams have elected to head back up to Camp II early tomorrow, but our plan is to take tomorrow off, and head back up on May 16th. We'll then take a rest day at Camp II, and target a summit on or about May 20th (when weather is also expected to be calm and hopefully clear).</blockquote>
<em></em>
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=20dcad50-340c-46fd-896e-ec4fea2f7e12" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Astronaut Summit Push #2 begins Saturday</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/15/astronaut-summit-push-2-begins-saturday/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 May 2009 04:35:16 +0000</pubDate>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=289</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Astronaut Scott Parazynski is now back at Everest Base Camp after a few days in lower, thicker air. After some bad weather - and bad luck on the mountain - in general, things are looking up. But on Everest, that can change in an instant. Right now, if all goes well, Scott will be on top of the world early on May 20th (which is evening May 19 in the US). But he is worried there will be an "Into Thin Air" traffic jam at the top. If that happens, he will wait another day. "It is not a race...it is a marathon," said Scott. You can read his blog at <a href="http://onorbit.com/everest">http://onorbit.com/everest</a> and track his every move in real time at <a href="http://www.spotadventures.com/">http://www.SPOTAdventures.com</a>.

[kaltura-widget wid="wcans9r8jo" width="410" height="364" addpermission="0" editpermission="0" /]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=4d46dbed-db61-44d8-8a89-70e9df76b9fd" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Science vs. Media - Good Blog Post</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/15/science-vs-media-good-blog-post/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 May 2009 10:04:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Journalism]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="journalism"><![CDATA[Journalism]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=308</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote><p>The media really sucks at presenting and explaining science. It's a common gripe among professional scientists, amateur scientists, and educated followers of science. I didn't always feel this way, myself. I used to be quite optimistic about the state of science reporting.</p>
<p>The media is interested in entertainment and the sale of advertisement. Selling information is not in their job description because the consumer isn't paying for it.</p></blockquote>
<p>via <a href="http://mychemicaljourney.blogspot.com/2009/05/science-v-media.html">My Chemical Journey: Science v. Media</a>.</p>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>NASA&#039;s next administrator ready to launch: Charles Bolden</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/15/nasas-next-administrator-ready-to-launch-charles-bolden/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 May 2009 17:35:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[African American]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="african-american"><![CDATA[African American]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Barack Obama]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="barack-obama"><![CDATA[Barack Obama]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Bill Nelson]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="bill-nelson"><![CDATA[Bill Nelson]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Charles Bolden]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="charles-bolden"><![CDATA[Charles Bolden]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Charlie Bolden]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="charlie-bolden"><![CDATA[Charlie Bolden]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Florida]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="florida"><![CDATA[Florida]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Lori Garver]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="lori-garver"><![CDATA[Lori Garver]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[White House]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="white-house"><![CDATA[White House]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=314</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div class="zemanta-img">

[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="190" caption="Image by Judge Rock via Flickr"]<a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/29981960@N06/3519745356"><img src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/05/3519745356_a3ce09cd0d_m.jpg" alt="Col CharlesBolden USMC" width="190" /></a>[/caption]

</div>
The stories you read about Charlie Bolden getting the nod as the next NASA Administrator have a good deal of truthiness to them. He is apparently teed up for the nation's premier space management gig, but that said, I am told he has not yet been officially been offered the job.

His name has been a stubborn occupant in the hopper of candidates for a lot of good reasons, African American born in the segregated south who makes it to Annapolis, the Marines, fighters, test piloting and eventually space shuttling. He was the commander of the mission before Challenger's last - carrying a young congressman from Florida by the name of Bill Nelson to space and back. Now Senator Nelson has worked tirelessly to lobby for his Commander. Bolden also happens to be a great guy who doesn't just have the right stuff - he knows his stuff.

So why did this take so long? Two issues: there is some concern that a former astronaut should not occupy the corner office on the 9th floor at NASA HQ - that they would focus too much on the white scarf squad - and not enough on NASA's chronically needy, yet scientifically significant robotic missions. And there is also the lobbying: Bolden has lobbied for the rocket builder ATK.

Apparently the White House is now over both issues - and soon Charlie Bolden will put "Code A" (NASA parlance for the Administrator) on his already storied resume.

As for who will be his deputy; the winner is Lori Garver - who has run the Obama transition at NASA. She is a former NASA deputy
administrator - and once tried a quixotic campaign to fly in space ("put a mom in tennis shoes in orbit" as I recall).

So now can we get on with the post shuttle plan already? The Space Cadet Nation should feel em-Boldened at this news.
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=30221406-77de-4a1c-8973-9b9e9c0fb2a0" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Bolden as NASA's Administrator is a great pick. Traditionally, the Deputy Administrator has been drawn from the technical ranks--think Hugh Dryden. Garver is the opposite end of that. I'm not sure what she brings to the that Bolden doesn't already have?

Given her head butting with Senator Nelson, I'd be surprised if she makes it to the number 2 spot. I mean, you are aware of some of the junk being fed to people about Nelson being irrelevant, the WH not listening to him, etc. that came from those camping out on the 9th Floor.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<title>Hubble Spacewalk #2 a Marathon</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/16/hubble-spacewalk-2-a-marathon/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 16 May 2009 11:15:44 +0000</pubDate>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=324</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-327" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/347213main_spacewalkers-vert12x16_1024-768.jpg" alt="347213main_spacewalkers-vert12x16_1024-768" width="245" height="227" />

<a href="http://spaceflightnow.com/shuttle/sts125/090515fd5/index4.html">Spaceflight Now | STS-125 Shuttle Report | Spacewalk No. 2 ends</a>.
<blockquote>Originally planned for six-and-a-half hours, the EVA began at 8:49 a.m. But problems getting one of three dual-gyro rate sensor units installed threw the astronauts well behind schedule. In the end, they had to forego one state-of-the-art gyro pack and instead install a refurbished RSU taken from Hubble during a 1999 service call.</blockquote>
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=b7fa07b3-6cf2-4313-a761-c45e187884eb" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

I'm assuming that Hubble has some method of moving about within its orbit to point at different areas of the sky, but no mention of propellants or replenishment has been made, at least that I have heard.

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://blogs.orlandosentinel.com/news_space_thewritestuff/2009/05/nelsons-push-for-nasa-cheif-may-pay-off.html"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-334" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/nelson.jpg" alt="nelson" width="218" height="257" />Orlando Sentinel - Nelson's "iron will" leads to NASA frontrunner</a>.
<blockquote>If retired Marine Corps Gen. and former astronaut <strong>Charlie Bolden</strong> emerges as the next NASA administrator he has one man to thank for it: Florida's senior Democratic Senator <strong>Bill Nelson.</strong>

Nelson has tirelessly -- some would say  obnoxiously -- pushed for his old friend and the man who piloted the shuttle that Nelson flew on in 1986, where earned the nickname “Ballast” from fellow astronauts.</blockquote>

		<title>Repaired spectrograph passes &#039;aliveness&#039; test</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/18/repaired-spectrograph-passes-aliveness-test/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 18 May 2009 11:12:09 +0000</pubDate>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Held up by a stripped screw, spacewalker Michael Massimino applied brute force muscle power to an otherwise delicate operation, breaking off an offending handrail and then carefully unscrewing more than 100 small fasteners to get inside a dead science instrument aboard the Hubble Space Telescope.

via <a href="http://www.spaceflightnow.com/shuttle/sts125/090517fd7/index5.html">Spaceflight Now | STS-125 Shuttle Report | Repaired spectrograph passes 'aliveness' test</a>.

<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=c405810e-63f0-43ca-9f5c-8d3adf6bd649" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Astronaut at Camp 3 - Carrying Moon Rocks</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/18/astronaut-at-camp-3-carrying-moon-rocks/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 18 May 2009 12:29:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="everest"><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=338</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align:left;">[kaltura-widget wid="9nbhxxlfxc" width="410" height="364" addpermission="0" editpermission="0" align="center" /]</p>
<p style="text-align:left;">Astronaut Scott Parazynski - buffeted now by high winds at Base Camp 3 - making a historic summit bid at Mount Everest - is carrying some small pieces of moon rock as he climbs to the top of the highest spot on Earth.</p>
<p style="text-align:left;">This sample was loaned to Parazynski by NASA which seldom gives out pieces of the lunar<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-353" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/everest_route_map.jpg" alt="everest_route_map" width="450" height="328" /> regolith gathered by the twelve Apollo astronauts who flew to the moon between 1969 and 1972.</p>

The lunar sample carried by Parazynski was collected by Apollo 11 Astronaut Neil Armstrong in July 1969. Numbered as sample 10085,134 this was one of the surface and subsurface samples picked up about 15-20 feet (4-6 meters) north of the Lunar Module "Eagle" which landed in the Sea of Tranquility.

If all goes according to plan (and it often does not on Everest), the rock fragments will reach the top of the world little more than two months before the fortieth anniversary of the Apollo 11 lunar landing.

This sample weighs 0.052 grams and is encapsulated in a clear acrylic "button" approximately 0.75 inches (1.9 cm) in diameter. The parent sample from which this smaller portion was taken weighed 569 grams (1.2 lbs).

A temporary outer enclosure was created at Everest Base Camp to further protect the sample, to allow it to be handled by people wearing thick mountaineering gloves, and to allow it to be more visible in photographs taken at the summit.
<div><img class="alignleft" src="http://images.spaceref.com/news/2009/IMG_4022.jpg" alt="" width="576" height="432" /></div>
<em>Image: close-up look at sample 10085,134 inside its protective housing</em>

These tiny rocks are left over from pieces embedded into so called "Small World" plaques that the US bestowed as gifts to other nations and to all fifty states in the seventies.

After his historic trip to the moon, Armstrong became close friends with the first man to summit Everest (in 1953) Sir Edmund Hillary. The two historic figures later traveled the world together - including a trip to the North Pole.

Parazynski was able to secure the moon rock loan via a Space Act Agreement in place between NASA and the <a href="http://www.challenger.org">Challenger Center for Space Science Education</a>. Parazynski's team includes Keith Cowing (located at Everest Base Camp), and Miles O'Brien (located in New York City). All three are members of the Board of Directors of the Challenger Center - established by family members of the crew of STS-51L shortly after the the shuttle accident in 1986.

There are currently more than fifty Challenger Centers all over the world - providing an immersive, stimulating learning environment for middle school students who role play simulated space missions.

During his Everest expedition, Parazynski answered dozens of questions posed by students at Challenger Centers all across the US via a satellite video link.

Parazynski is sponsored by the SPOT Satellite Messenger Company - a unit of Globalstar. The SPOT device enables Internet users to track his steps in real time at <a href="http://www.spotadventures.com/">http://www.SPOTAdventures.com</a>.

This is Parazynski's second consecutive season on Everest. Last year, he was in striking distance of he summit when a back injury forced him to turn back and hobble down the mountain. Thanks to some surgery and a rigorous exercise regimen, he is in great physical shape to achieve his lifelong goal this year.

Parazynski flew five times on the space shuttle (including one mission as a crew mate of Senator John Glenn) and performed seven spacewalks (including a daring improvised trip into the void in 2007 to unsnarl a snagged solar array at the International Space Station). He retired from the astronaut corps in March and is now employed by Wyle Labs in Houston.

The moon rocks will be returned to NASA once Parazynski comes home.

Parazynski hopes to summit in the early hours of May 20 on Everest - evening May 19 in the US.
<div><img src="http://images.spaceref.com/news/2009/IMG_4026mod.jpg" alt="" /></div>
<em>Image: Scott holding up moon rock sample 10085,134 inside its protective housing so as to eclipse the rising moon. The west shoulder of Mt. Everest is on the left.</em>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-05-18 12:29:19</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>astronaut-at-camp-3-carrying-moon-rocks</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

		<pubDate>Tue, 19 May 2009 00:42:03 +0000</pubDate>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=356</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>If inanimate objects had personalities, the Hubble space telescope would be described as having the hide of a rhinoceros. The launch was delayed for several years by the Challenger disaster, and by the time it went up into the upper atmosphere it had cost over six times its original estimate. Within weeks of its launch, it was found to have a flaw in its super-finely ground mirror.</blockquote>
via <a href="http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2009/may/18/in-praise-of-hubble-telescope">In praise of ... the Hubble telescope | Editorial | Comment is free | The Guardian</a>.]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Astronaut on His Way to the Top of Everest</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/05/19/astronaut-on-his-way-to-the-top-of-everest/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 19 May 2009 15:04:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Astronaut]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="astronaut"><![CDATA[Astronaut]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Climbing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="climbing"><![CDATA[Climbing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Earth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="earth"><![CDATA[Earth]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="everest"><![CDATA[Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Everest Base Camp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="everest-base-camp"><![CDATA[Everest Base Camp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mount-everest"><![CDATA[Mount Everest]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mountain]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mountain"><![CDATA[Mountain]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mountaineering]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mountaineering"><![CDATA[Mountaineering]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[mountaineers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mountaineers"><![CDATA[mountaineers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Nepal]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nepal"><![CDATA[Nepal]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Scott E. Parazynski]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="scott-e-parazynski"><![CDATA[Scott E. Parazynski]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Scott Parazynski]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="scott-parazynski"><![CDATA[Scott Parazynski]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=408</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-269" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/05/img_3964-225x300.jpg" alt="img_3964" width="171" height="227" />Astronaut Scott Parazynski woke up and shoved off from the last stop before the Summit of Everest - the High Camp - at about 10:45am ET - 8:30pm on Everest. He and his IMG teammates will climb through the night toward the summit, and assuming all goes well, will be there for a dawn that can only be topped...from space I suppose. If he makes it, Scott will be the first and only human to see a sunrise from orbit and from the highest point on Earth.

I spoke with Keith Cowing, who is helping Scott get his story out, back at Everest base Camp at about 10:30am ET. He says there is a medical emergency on the mountain now, which might - or might not - delay Scott  (who is a physician in addition to being an astronaut).

As it stands right now, Scott should be on the summit at about 7pm ET tonight- or <img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-353" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/05/everest_route_map-300x218.jpg" alt="everest_route_map" width="300" height="218" />4:45am/May 20 on Everest. Stay with me here...and follow the adventure as well on the following twitter feeds: <a href="http://twitter.com/milesobrien">@milesobrien</a> <a href="http://twitter.com/keithcowing">@keithcowing</a> <a href="http://twitter.com/SPOTScott">@SPOTScott.</a>

Scott's blog is at <a href="http://onorbit.com/everest">http://onorbit.com/everest</a>

And perhaps the coolest thing: Scott is carrying a <a href="http://www.findmespot.com/en/">SPOT Satellite Messenger</a> Device - which will provide real-time tracking data on his location. Follow him there at <a href="http://www.spotadventures.com/">http://www.SPOTAdventures.com</a>
<p style="text-align:center;">[kaltura-widget wid="dravewstcb" width="410" height="364" addpermission="0" editpermission="0" align="center" /]</p>

<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=72dd480d-7b1f-43b7-8905-6b4be8babacd" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
