		<wp:comment_author_IP>172.20.1.232</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2009-08-13 21:08:18</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-08-14 01:08:18</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA["Like moths to a porch light." Careful, Buddy - that's darn near Ratherian. :-)

I appreciate your candor in these pieces. It's refreshing. I hope I'm not the only one listening -- or maybe I'd be better off hoping you're not the only voice of reason in this.]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
		<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
		<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
			</item>
		<item>
		<title>Hudson River Crash a Tragic Fluke</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/08/10/hudson-river-crash-a-tragic-fluke/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 10 Aug 2009 14:04:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Air traffic control]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="air-traffic-control"><![CDATA[Air traffic control]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Aircraft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="aircraft"><![CDATA[Aircraft]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="aviation"><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Fixed-wing aircraft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fixed-wing-aircraft"><![CDATA[Fixed-wing aircraft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Hudson River]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="hudson-river"><![CDATA[Hudson River]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[New York]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="new-york"><![CDATA[New York]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[New York City]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="new-york-city"><![CDATA[New York City]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Statue of Liberty]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="statue-of-liberty"><![CDATA[Statue of Liberty]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Teterboro Airport]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="teterboro-airport"><![CDATA[Teterboro Airport]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[US]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="us"><![CDATA[US]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1059</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1063" align="alignleft" width="200" caption="Tourist photos of the collision of a helicopter and a small plane over the Hudson River in New York on Saturday(Screen grab via Fox News)"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/08/hudsoncollision.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-1063" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/08/hudsoncollision.jpg" alt="Tourist photos of the collision of a helicopter and a small plane over the Hudson River in New York on Saturday(Screen grab via Fox News)" width="200" height="300" /></a>[/caption]

The pilots simply never saw each other.

Steven Altman had just departed Teterboro Airport in his single-engine airplane – his brother and nephew aboard. They were heading to the Hudson River flight corridor – and eventually out the mouth of New York Harbor toward the Jersey shore. As he reached the river, he turned his low-wing plane steeply to the right to begin hugging the west bank of the Hudson – the proper place for southbound traffic.

At precisely that moment, Jeremy Clarke took off from the 30th Street Heliport in a Eurocopter carrying five tourists from Italy. As he gained altitude, he flew across the river, and turned to the left to fly down to the Statue of Liberty.

As they converged, Altman would have been in the left front seat of his plane looking to his right – while Clarke was in the right front seat of the chopper - looking left.

The low wing on Altman’s airplane would have completely obscured the chopper. In a climbing left turn, Clarke’s view of the airplane would have been obscured by the rotors above him.

There is a long history of so called “low-wing/high-wing” mid air collisions. Most of the time, they happen near smaller airports that do not have a control tower.

In this case it happened a very busy slice of the sky – the virtual tunnel for airplane traffic over the Hudson River.

Those of us who fly through this airspace are responsible for seeing and avoiding each other. There are no air traffic controllers serving as traffic cops here.

And before you get yourself all spun up about this (I am talkin’ to you Sen. Schumer!), before this tragic crash there has never been a mid air collision like this in New York City.

Over the years, many thousands of airplane and helicopters have successfully and safely plied their way through this corridor of airspace wherein the responsibility for collision avoidance rests entirely in the cockpit.

And the real truth is it makes flying in the New York City airspace safer – because all the aircraft who fly in this zone are not taxing already maxed out air traffic controllers.

If tour helicopters had to check in with ATC every time they alighted with a load of tourists, the system would bog down in a hurry.

It is NOT the Wild West up there - as <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/10/nyregion/10collide.html">one congressional staffer</a> suggests. Not by a long shot. There are rules that pilots follow and the safety record speaks for itself.

It is a busy place with a lot of traffic and you have to pay attention all the time. But that’s New York for you. When two cars collide in Midtown Manhattan, do we instantly insist the traffic laws be changed?

The odds of this accident happening were long indeed. If either pilot had taken off five or ten seconds later (or earlier) it would not have happened.

It is a terrible tragedy and we all mourn the needless loss of life. But it was, statistically, a black swan – and not the result of some endemic, systemic flaw. Let’s resist the temptation to try and fix a system that is not broken. More often than not, the unintended consequences simply make matters worse.
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=68dc3f84-038c-4bb5-93d7-66e0ded4810f" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-08-10 16:41:41</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I have disagree with your assessment of the state of reality in the corridor.  If pilots only had to contend with seeing and avoiding other aircraft that were flying at 1000ft up and down the Hudson, then I'd be right there with you.

However, given the amount of helicopter traffic constantly climbing and descending through that airspace, combined with the shear density of the traffic there, I think the situation is unreasonably precarious.  Consider the fact that helicopter traffic is apparently significantly more abundant over the Hudson these days as a result of the East River closure.

For that reason, I don't think the lack of mid-airs in the past can be used as a track record for the future.

Perhaps a relatively simple change that could be made is the introduction of a SECOND corridor, above the existing one, specifically for aircraft transitioning the area. This would involve raising the bravo floor, though.

In lieu of that, I think fixed wing aircraft transitioning the area should do it in the Bravo on the existing LGA/TWR Bravo freqs.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I absolutely agree -- the only thing I wonder is: would a traffic advisory system (TAS) have helped here?  The Piper was an older plane, and I don't know how updated its avionics were, but it doesn't seem unreasonable to me to require aircraft flying commercially in the corridor (like the helicopter was) to install TAS.

Even if one of these two aircraft had had a good TAS system, it seems likely that they could have taken evasive action.

My airplane is over 50 years old, and I'm installing TAS as part of a panel refit before I move it to the busy SF Bay Area.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
		<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
		<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
				<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>1284</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[timothyshea]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>shea@acm.org</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>172.20.1.232</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2009-08-13 10:24:47</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-08-13 14:24:47</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Miles, when the accident happened, I looked up procedures for the Hudson corridor. They weren’t obvious. The VFR chart and procedures should be improved.

Take a look at the New York Terminal Area Chart. This is what most pilots will use. It has a large-scale view of the entire NY area on the front. The heliport in question is shown (tiny amidst a lot of clutter). You can’t see much detail on the Hudson. Clearly this chart is not suitable for navigating the corridor. (Front of chart: http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2437/3805486160_c518b5c45b_o.jpg)

On the back is a small helicopter inset. The remaining ¾ of the chart is blank. (Back of chart: http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3441/3804638279_25b5714270_o.jpg) This is what pilots will use when flying the Hudson corridor, because the scale &amp; detail are appropriate. However The actual corridor isn’t shown (only a small part of the southern end). The heliport in question isn’t shown. Despite the fact that 30,000 tour flights a year depart from it (average about 80/day, probably double that on nice days). Routes &amp; altitudes typically flown by the tour operators aren’t shown. Despite the fact that they tend to be repetitive and predictable. Few general aviation reporting points are shown. The proper frequency is given, and some mention of helicopter activity down around the Statue of Liberty at 500 feet is made. The accident occurred much farther north, around 1,100, based on the radar track. (Detailed image, large: http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3130/3804777444_f5f11159d0_o.jpg)

There are many “corridors” in the US, including one over Los Angeles International, and one along the coast adjacent. They serve a similar function: Allow safe movement of VFR traffic, separating it from controlled / commercial traffic.

Contrast this with the Niagara Falls procedures. General Aviation traffic flies a defined route, remaining above 3,500 ft. Helicopter tours remain below 3,500 ft. Everyone talks on the same frequency. It’s pretty simple. (Chart: http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3596/3586096482_a9be0234ee_o.jpg)

VFR flight under ATC in the NY area is possible. One can either (a) enter the Class B airspace under ATC control, or (b) request VFR advisories from ATC when outside it (e.g. when flying over, under, or adjacent). The NY controllers are competent and professional. But often very busy. When I overflew NY at 11,500 ft (3 weeks ago) I was on VFR advisories. However as I approached NY, the controllers had to drop me. They were too busy. The frequency was non-stop. Controllers must prioritize. Overload them, and they can make mistakes too. Additional VFR traffic will add to their load.

The NY Terminal Area chart should be improved, to show the entire Hudson corridor. Procedures for that airspace should be made simple and obvious. High-density helicopter routes (e.g. tours) should be shown, and clear radio reporting points identified. That way everyone knows what to do, and expect.]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
		<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
		<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
				<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>1285</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[timothyshea]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>shea@acm.org</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>172.20.1.232</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2009-08-13 10:28:34</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-08-13 14:28:34</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Miles, when the accident happened, I looked up procedures for the Hudson corridor. They weren’t obvious. The VFR chart and procedures should be improved.

Take a look at the New York Terminal Area Chart. This is what most pilots will use. It has a large-scale view of the entire NY area on the front. The heliport in question is shown (tiny amidst a lot of clutter). You can’t see much detail on the Hudson. Clearly this chart is not suitable for navigating the corridor. (Front of chart:  http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2437/3805486160_c518b5c45b_o.jpg )

On the back is a small helicopter inset. The remaining ¾ of the chart is blank. (Back of chart:  http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3441/3804638279_25b5714270_o.jpg ) This is what pilots will use when flying the Hudson corridor, because the scale &amp; detail are appropriate. However The actual corridor isn’t shown (only a small part of the southern end). The heliport in question isn’t shown. Despite the fact that 30,000 tour flights a year depart from it. Routes &amp; altitudes flown by the tour operators aren’t shown. Few general aviation reporting points are shown. The proper frequency is given, and some mention of helicopter activity down around the Statue of Liberty at 500 feet is made. The accident occurred farther north, around 1,100. (Detailed image, large:  http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3130/3804777444_f5f11159d0_o.jpg )

There are many “corridors” in the US, including one over Los Angeles International, and one along the coast adjacent. They allow safe movement of VFR traffic, and separate it from controlled / commercial traffic.

Contrast this with the Niagara Falls procedures. General Aviation flies a defined route, remaining above 3,500 ft. Helicopter tours remain below 3,500 ft. Everyone talks on the same frequency. It’s pretty simple. (Chart:  http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3596/3586096482_a9be0234ee_o.jpg )

VFR flight under ATC in the NY area is possible. One can either (a) enter the Class B airspace under ATC control, or (b) request VFR advisories from ATC when outside it (e.g. when flying over, under, or adjacent). The NY controllers are competent and professional. But often very busy. When I overflew NY at 11,500 ft (3 weeks ago) I was on VFR advisories. However as I approached NY, the controllers had to drop me. They were too busy. The frequency was non-stop. Controllers must prioritize. Overload them, and they can make mistakes too. Additional VFR traffic will add to their load.

The NY Terminal Area chart should be improved, to show the entire Hudson corridor. Procedures for that airspace should be made simple and obvious. High-density helicopter routes (e.g. tours) should be shown, and clear radio reporting points identified. That way everyone knows what to do, and expect.]]></wp:comment_content>

<ul>
	<li>Producer/Correspondent/Post-Production Manager David Waters (<a title="David Waters Productions" href="http://www.davidwatersproductions.com/wordpress/" target="_blank">David Waters Productions</a>)</li>
	<li>Executive Producer Kate Tobin (<a title="Kate Tobin Productions" href="http://www.katetobin.com" target="_blank">Kate Tobin Productions</a> and <a title="Grow Your Imagination" href="http://www.GrowYourImaginaton.com" target="_blank">Grow Your Imagination</a> Blog)</li>

	<li><a href="http://cg4tv.com/virtual-set" target="blank">Virtual set</a> and <a href="http://cg4tv.com/animated-backgrounds" target="blank">background animations</a> by CG4TV.com</li>

</ul>
Thanks to all!

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignright size-thumbnail wp-image-1234" title="twis300" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/12/twis3001-150x150.jpg" alt="twis300" width="150" height="150" />Welcome to the premier of "This Week In Space With Miles O'Brien," a new show dedicated to keeping space lovers up to speed on the stories and issues making news off the planet.

This is Part 3of 3, and features news on the the WISE Spacecraft Launch, the rollout of Virgin Galactic's SpaceShipTwo, new images from the recently refurbished Hubble Space Telescope, Butterflies in Space, and an interview with astronaut Nicole Stott - just back from the ISS.

[youtubevid id="YVuubNt-vNM"]

		<title>Everything Old Is New Again</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/21/everything-old-is-new-again/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 15:04:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Earth]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1069</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1191" align="alignright" width="148" caption="Earliest view of Earth from the Moon.  Source: Lunar Orbiter Images Recovery Project/NASA Ames"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1191" title="first-earth-from-moon" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/first-earth-from-moon.jpg?w=148" alt="First view of Earth from the Moon.  Source: Lunar Orbiter Images Recovery Project/NASA Ames" width="148" height="300" />[/caption]

Next time on “This Week In Space” - we will take you to <a href="http://www.moonviews.com/" target="_blank">McMoons</a> - believe it or not the old McDonald's at <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/home/index.html" target="_blank">NASA Ames Research Center</a> has become the scene of a remarkable project to preserve and enhance some 50 year old pictures of the moon...

We'll tell you the amazing tale of the lost tapes - jury rigged antique machines - and some guys with a lot of drive and passion...the only question is: would you like a hot apple pie with that?]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Butterflies Are Free</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/21/butterflies-are-free/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 15:05:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Astronaut]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="astronaut"><![CDATA[Astronaut]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Butterflies]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="butterflies"><![CDATA[Butterflies]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Butterfly]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="butterfly"><![CDATA[Butterfly]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Caterpillar]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="caterpillar"><![CDATA[Caterpillar]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Flickr]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="flickr"><![CDATA[Flickr]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="international-space-station"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iss"><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Twitter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="twitter"><![CDATA[Twitter]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1072</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1188" align="alignright" width="300" caption="International Space Station.  Source:  NASA"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1188" title="ISS" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/iss.jpg?w=300" alt="International Space Station.  Source:  NASA" width="300" height="204" />[/caption]

You think Muhammad Ali could float like a butterfly? - well wait to you see some butterflies who can float like an astronaut...

These<a title="BioEd Online" href="http://www.bioedonline.org/space/STS_Mission_129.cfm" target="_blank"> Monarchs and Painted Ladies</a> launched as caterpillars - and emerged from their pupa stage - aboard the International Space Station - they are the first adult butterflies to have flown in space.

Clearly they were confused - and did not know which was up  - as you might have hypothesized.

More than 170,000 K-12 students are following the butterflies exploits.  You can follow their adventures on <a title="Flickr - Butterflies in Space STS-129" href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/32587739@N07/sets/72157622645748488/" target="_blank">Flickr</a> or on <a title="Twitter - ButterflySpace" href="http://twitter.com/#search?q=ButterflySpace" target="_blank">Twitter</a> - their handle there is ButterflySpace.

[youtubevid id="c9SMNU-_P3w"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=1fbb3ba1-cfe2-4f6e-9dc3-65adfdd62e04" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1072</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-12-21 10:05:14</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-12-21 15:05:14</wp:post_date_gmt>

		<item>
		<title>Nicole Stott - Back on Terra Firma</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/21/nicole-stott-back-on-terra-firma/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 15:10:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="international-space-station"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iss"><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1074</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1162" align="alignright" width="200" caption="Nicole Stott.  Source:  NASA"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1162" title="NicoleStott" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/12/NicoleStott-200x300.jpg" alt="Nicole Stott.  Source:  NASA" width="200" height="300" />[/caption]

<a title="NASA - Nicole Stott Biography" href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/stott-np.html" target="_blank">Nicole Stott</a> is just back from a three month tour of duty on-orbit.   Our David Waters checked in to see how gravity's treating her.  Here's the <a title="Nicole Stott Interview" href="http://idisk.me.com/katobin/Public/Nicole Stott Interview for Transcription_1-2.doc" target="_blank">transcript</a> of the interview.

Nicole's name will go into the history books on two fronts:
<ul>
	<li>She was the last station crew member to rotate on and off the ISS via the space shuttle.  From now on, all crew crew members will go up and down on the Russian Soyuz.</li>
	<li>She's been assigned to the crew of STS-133...the final space shuttle mission.</li>
</ul>
Here are some remarks she made to NASA TV after her return.

[youtubevid id="f0qG7LDjlXM"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=cfb6e50a-3c99-44f8-a934-bd68135e5101" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Go Deep! Go Really, Really Deep!</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/21/go-deep-go-really-really-deep/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 15:11:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Astronomy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="astronomy"><![CDATA[Astronomy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Big Bang]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="big-bang"><![CDATA[Big Bang]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Galaxy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="galaxy"><![CDATA[Galaxy]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Hubble]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="hubble"><![CDATA[Hubble]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Hubble Ultra Deep Field]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="hubble-ultra-deep-field"><![CDATA[Hubble Ultra Deep Field]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Images]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="images"><![CDATA[Images]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Wide Field Camera 3]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="wide-field-camera-3"><![CDATA[Wide Field Camera 3]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1076</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1165" align="alignright" width="200" caption="Hubble Space Telescope.  Source:  NASA"]<img class="size-full wp-image-1165" title="Hubble" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/hubble.jpg" alt="Hubble Space Telescope.  Source:  NASA" width="200" height="200" />[/caption]

The Benjamin Button of Space Telescopes...old/young man <a title="Hubble's Deepest View of Universe Unveils Never-Before-Seen Galaxies" href="http://hubblesite.org/newscenter/archive/releases/2009/31/" target="_blank">Hubble</a> is wowing us once again... this time going back back back - further in time than ever.

Astronomers trained the new <a title="NASA - Hubble WFC 3 Factsheet" href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/hubble/servicing/SM4/main/WFC3_FS_HTML.html" target="_blank">Wide Field Camera 3</a> on the same patch of sky where Hubble captured the famous <a title="Hubble Ultra Deep Field" href="http://hubblesite.org/newscenter/archive/releases/2004/07/" target="_blank">Ultra Deep Field </a>image in 2004.

The new image took 173,000 seconds of exposure time over 4 days - and reveals the oldest galaxies ever imaged - only 6 to 900 million years after the Big Bang.

Now that's a time exposure - in more ways than one.

[vimeovid id="8264104"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=db8aa089-480d-40df-bb5e-b1f0d502d891" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

		<item>
		<title>SpaceShipTwo Rollout</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/21/spaceshiptwo-rollout/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 15:13:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="aviation"><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Business]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="business"><![CDATA[Business]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[California]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="california"><![CDATA[California]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Commercial Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="commercial-space"><![CDATA[Commercial Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Richard Branson]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="richard-branson"><![CDATA[Richard Branson]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Scaled Composite]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="scaled-composite"><![CDATA[Scaled Composite]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Scaled Composites SpaceShipTwo]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="scaled-composites-spaceshiptwo"><![CDATA[Scaled Composites SpaceShipTwo]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Scaled Composites WhiteKnightTwo]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="scaled-composites-whiteknighttwo"><![CDATA[Scaled Composites WhiteKnightTwo]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Spacecraft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="spacecraft"><![CDATA[Spacecraft]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Virgin Galactic]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="virgin-galactic"><![CDATA[Virgin Galactic]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1081</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1159" align="alignright" width="300" caption="SpaceShipTwo.  Courtesy:  Virgin Galactic"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1159" title="SpaceShipTwo" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/spaceshiptwo.jpg?w=300" alt="SpaceShipTwo.  Courtesy:  Virgin Galactic" width="300" height="262" />[/caption]

The hangar door is sealed tight once again at Burt Rutan's shop in Mojave California.  The<a title="Scaled Composites" href="http://www.scaled.com" target="_blank"> Scaled Composites</a> team focused on the nitty gritty details of getting SpaceShipTwo ready to carry some paying passengers to space.

If they fly like they put on a show - <a title="Virgin Galactic" href="http://www.virgingalactic.com/" target="_blank">Virgin Galactic</a> is bound to dazzle...about 500 hundred would be fliers, politicians and VIP's were there on December 7th - for the rollout of Space Ship Two.  Richard Branson says his ship nearly brought him to tears...

[vimeovid id="8267108"]

After the rollout  - a fluke storm came barreling in to Mojave...the revelers had to beat a hasty retreat - and some high winds tore the elaborate tent to shreds. Fortunately SpaceshipTwo and her mothership White Knight 2 were safely tucked in their hangar.

I don't believe in omens...do you?

[vimeovid id="8267108"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=3f1e7a0a-5071-4afc-b989-59571b3783dc" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>OH A WISE Guy - eh?</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/21/oh-a-wise-guy-eh/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 15:15:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Astronomy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="astronomy"><![CDATA[Astronomy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Infrared]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="infrared"><![CDATA[Infrared]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Near-Earth object]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="near-earth-object"><![CDATA[Near-Earth object]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Solar System]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="solar-system"><![CDATA[Solar System]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Spacecraft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="spacecraft"><![CDATA[Spacecraft]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="wide-field-infrared-survey-explorer"><![CDATA[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1079</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1185" align="alignright" width="300" caption="WISE Spacecraft.  Source:  NASA/JPL"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1185" title="WISE" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/wise1.jpg?w=300" alt="WISE Spacecraft.  Source:  NASA/JPL" width="300" height="255" />[/caption]

Somewhere up there Curly Howard is nyuck nyuck nyucking over this one. NASA's Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer  - or <a title="NASA - WISE Page" href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/WISE/main/index.html" target="_blank">WISE </a>- spacecraft left the pad at Vandenberg Air Force Base - is now on its way to scan the heavens in unprecedented ways.

[youtubevid id="45NAENHol24"]

NASA hopes WISE will orbit the earth from pole to pole for about ten months - snapping millions of infrared images - casting a wide net for cool things - and I mean that literally - things like brown dwarfs - an near earth asteroids and comets - which are hard for us to see otherwise.

[vimeovid id="8264399"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=7757ed0a-403a-4a99-8422-a34cebd4ad1a" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignright size-thumbnail wp-image-1257" title="twis300" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/12/twis3002-150x150.jpg" alt="twis300" width="150" height="150" />Welcome to the premier of "This Week In Space With Miles O'Brien," a new show dedicated to keeping space lovers up to speed on the stories and issues making news off the planet.

This is Part 2 of 3, and features news on the Mars Recon Orbiter and the Mars rover Spirit, an interview with former NASA Administrator Mike Griffin on the future of the U.S. manned spaceflight program, and updates on Endeavour and the ISS.

[youtubevid id="TWEiNwlm8cU"]

		<item>
		<title>Tally ho, Alpha!</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/21/tally-ho-alpha/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 15:24:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Baikonur Cosmodrome]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="baikonur-cosmodrome"><![CDATA[Baikonur Cosmodrome]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Expedition 22]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="expedition-22"><![CDATA[Expedition 22]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Expedition 22]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="expedition-22"><![CDATA[Expedition 22]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iss"><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Oleg Kotov]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="oleg-kotov"><![CDATA[Oleg Kotov]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Russian Orthodox Church]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="russian-orthodox-church"><![CDATA[Russian Orthodox Church]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Soichi Noguchi]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="soichi-noguchi"><![CDATA[Soichi Noguchi]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1121</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1168" align="alignright" width="200" caption="Expedition 22 Crew.  Source:  NASA"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1168" title="Exp22Crew" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/exp22crew.jpg?w=200" alt="Expedition 22 Crew.  Source:  NASA" width="200" height="300" />[/caption]

Meanwhile some reinforcements are on the way to the station - <a title="NASA - Expedition 22 " href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition22/index.html" target="_blank">Expedition 22</a> - including <a title="NASA - Oleg Kotov Biography" href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/kotov-ov.html" target="_blank">Oleg Kotov</a>, <a title="NASA - Soichi Noguchi Biography" href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/noguchi.html" target="_blank">Soichi Noguchi</a>, and <a title="NASA - T.J. Creamer" href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/creamer.html" target="_blank">T.J. Creamer </a>- are slated for launch 4:51pm Eastern  2151 GMT on December 20th - Before they leave - they will be blessed by a Russian Orthodox priest, sign a door in the room where Gagarin slept - watch a movie called "the white sun of the desert" and then finally - pee on the bus tire as they near the launch pad (because Yuri did, silly). Then and only then will they be deemed fit and ready for launch.

By the time you watch this, they may have already departed.  Be sure to check out <a title="Spaceflight Now" href="http://www.spaceflightnow.com" target="_blank">Spaceflightnow.com</a> for live mission updates as they happen.
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=64fd240a-866c-4ccd-9589-ffc2645ed613" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>But Did He Catch the Golden Snitch?</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/21/but-did-he-catch-the-golden-snitch/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 15:25:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Astronaut]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="astronaut"><![CDATA[Astronaut]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Harry Potter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="harry-potter"><![CDATA[Harry Potter]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iss"><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Jeff Williams]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="jeff-williams"><![CDATA[Jeff Williams]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="massachusetts-institute-of-technology"><![CDATA[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Quidditch]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="quidditch"><![CDATA[Quidditch]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1118</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1176" align="alignright" width="300" caption="SPHERES in the Destiny Laboratory.  Source: NASA"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1176" title="SPHERES" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/spheres.jpg?w=300" alt="SPHERES in the Destiny Laboratory.  Source: NASA" width="300" height="198" />[/caption]

Up on station, it looked a little like a Harry Potter movie the other day - astronaut<a title="NASA - Jeff Williams Biography" href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/williamsj.html" target="_blank"> Jeff Williams</a> broke out what appear to be a pair of Bludgers - used in the game Quidditch. Actually it is part of an MIT experiment called <a title="MIT SPHERES" href="http://ssl.mit.edu/spheres/" target="_blank">SPHERES</a> to test autonomous formation flying.

Cool stuff - but clearly Williams's crew mate on the treadmill, <a title="NASA - Maxim Suraev Biography" href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/suraev.html" target="_blank">Max Suraev</a>, was unimpressed - must be a Muggle.

[vimeovid id="8295325"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=490cbd17-0c7e-4ea6-aa28-c5177536ffa5" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Endeavour Snug in the VAB for the Holidays</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/21/endeavour-snug-in-the-vab-for-the-holidays/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 15:26:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle-endeavour"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle external tank]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle-external-tank"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle external tank]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Vehicle Assembly Building]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="vehicle-assembly-building"><![CDATA[Vehicle Assembly Building]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1116</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1179" align="alignright" width="200" caption="Endeavour in the VAB.  Source:  NASA"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1179" title="Endeavour" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/endeavour.jpg?w=200" alt="Endeavour in the VAB.  Source:  NASA" width="200" height="300" />[/caption]

The orbiter <a title="NASA - Shuttle Main Page" href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/main/index.html" target="_blank">Endeavour</a> is now looking up - the other day at the cape - workers moved her from the Orbiter Processing Facility to the Vehicle  to the Vehicle Assembly Building - to be mated with her external fuel tank and solid rocket boosters.
The shuttle will roll-out to pad 39A after the holidays on track for an early February launch to the station.

[youtubevid id="iz7KyMV6zcE"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=40d3ce7f-2b1f-4fe0-9454-dcbaf083cb77" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>It&#039;s All About Politics</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/21/its-all-about-politics/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 15:28:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Augustine Committee]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="augustine-committee"><![CDATA[Augustine Committee]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Barack Obama]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="barack-obama"><![CDATA[Barack Obama]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Commercial Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="commercial-space"><![CDATA[Commercial Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Constellation]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="constellation"><![CDATA[Constellation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Constellation program]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="constellation-program"><![CDATA[Constellation program]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[humanspaceflight]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="humanspaceflight"><![CDATA[humanspaceflight]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iss"><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="mars"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Moon]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="moon"><![CDATA[Moon]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Nancy Pelosi]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nancy-pelosi"><![CDATA[Nancy Pelosi]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Politics]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="politics"><![CDATA[Politics]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space exploration]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-exploration"><![CDATA[Space exploration]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Vision for Space Exploration]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="vision-for-space-exploration"><![CDATA[Vision for Space Exploration]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1136</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1144" align="alignright" width="200" caption="Ares I-X Launch.  Source:  NASA/Scott Andrews, Cannon"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1144" title="AresI-X2" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/aresi-x2.jpg?w=200" alt="Source:  NASA/Scott Andrews, Cannon" width="200" height="300" />[/caption]

More on NASA's future. It appears President Obama is close to making a decision on which course to chart in space.   Whenever he shares HIS vision with the rest of us - the debate will  move to a broader realm - and of course to Congress - where nothing is guaranteed.

The other day , Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi showed her colors in a gabfest with reporters:
<blockquote>“I, myself, if you are asking me personally, I have not been a big fan of manned expeditions to outer space, in terms of safety and cost,” Pelosi told reporters a round table on legislative accomplishments this year. “But people could make the case; technology is always changing.”</blockquote>
Oh, boy.  Fortunately for space fans, there are some people in Congress who do their homework - and are strong supporters of manned spaceflight.

And as it turns out, many of them are big fans of the Bush "Vision for Space Exploration."

Among the big supporters is the chairwoman of the <a title="House Committee on Science &amp; Technology" href="http://science.house.gov/subcommittee/space.aspx" target="_blank">House Subcommittee on Space and Aeronautics</a>, <a title="Gabrielle Giffords" href="http://giffords.house.gov/" target="_blank">Gabrielle Giffords</a> - a democrat of Arizona - who is married to NASA astronaut <a title="NASA - Mark Kelly Biography" href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/kellyme.html" target="_blank">Mark Kelly</a>.

On December 2 she held a hearing on the pros and cons of constellation versus commercial alternatives. And it seems clear where she stands:
<blockquote>"We hope to hear from our witnesses as to whether they believe that the burden of proof should be put on those who would propose alternatives to the Constellation program to demonstrate that their systems will be at least as safe as Ares/Orion. Alternatively, do they think it would it be acceptable to reduce the required level of crew safety on commercially provided crew transport services used to transport U.S. astronauts much below what looks to be achievable in the Constellation program?"</blockquote>
I guess you could call that a loaded question...In any case, if he had been in the room that day - former NASA  Administrator <a title="NASA - Mike Griffin Biography" href="http://www.nasa.gov/about/highlights/griffin_bio.html" target="_blank">Mike Griffin</a> might have stood up raised his hands and said "Amen!"  OK, well maybe the man who once likened himself to Spock would have been a bit more reserved - but he does firmly believes NASA should press on with <a title="NASA - Constellation" href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/constellation/main/index.html" target="_blank">Ares and Constellation</a> as it is currently envisioned.

One of the big things he is worried about the the time between vehicles - the infamous "Gap."  Watch below, or read the <a title="Griffin Interview" href="http://idisk.me.com/katobin/Public/Michael D. Griffin on 2009-12-12 at 09.10.doc" target="_blank">transcript</a> of our interview.

[vimeovid id="8266023"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=724d03c5-0b00-40ba-a3b9-87bcfbd1f019" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[186]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
		<item>
		<title>Spirit - Wheel Woes</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/21/spirit-wheel-woes/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 15:30:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="jet-propulsion-laboratory"><![CDATA[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="mars"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mars"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Rover]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="rover"><![CDATA[Rover]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Spirit rover]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="spirit-rover"><![CDATA[Spirit rover]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1114</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1172" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Mars Exploration Rover.  Source:  NASA/JPL"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1172" title="MER" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/mer.jpg?w=300" alt="Mars Exploration Rover.  Source:  NASA/JPL" width="300" height="240" />[/caption]

Meanwhile - down on rust colored surface - Spirit is looking a lot like me when I take to the links - that is to say stuck in a sand trap.

The problem is the plucky rover <a title="NASA - MER Page" href="http://marsrover.nasa.gov/home/index.html" target="_blank">Spirit</a> has a right rear wheel that has gone Tango Uniform (as in Toes Up). Three years ago Spirit's right front wheel failed - so now the Rover has only one working drive wheel on the right side - making an extrication from the sand unlikely.

But the never say die team at <a href="http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/">JPL</a> is still working on it - and during a recent troubleshooting session that long-broken front wheel actually moved a bit!

Prospects for any sort of full recovery remain bleak, however.  The best they may be able to do tilt Spirit so its solar arrays will still generate enough juice to stay alive during winter - which comes in May.

[vimeovid id="8266606"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=11f96445-40b3-407b-b6ed-ed5c3f959355" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>MRO - Safe Mode No More</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/21/mro-safe-mode-no-more/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 15:32:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="aviation"><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mars"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mars-reconnaissance-orbiter"><![CDATA[Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Safe mode]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="safe-mode"><![CDATA[Safe mode]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1108</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1155" align="alignright" width="300" caption="MRO.  Source:  NASA/JPL"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1155" title="MRO_image_br" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/12/MRO_image_br1-300x262.jpg" alt="MRO.  Source:  NASA/JPL" width="300" height="262" />[/caption]

NASA's <a title="NASA - MRO Site" href="http://mars.jpl.nasa.gov/mro/" target="_blank">Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter</a> is on the mend after a long stint in intensive care - what the wizards at the <a title="NASA - JPL" href="http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/" target="_blank">Jet Propulsion Lab</a> call "safe mode."

Engineers there were able to upload some new software - which they hope will stop MRO's computers from spontaneously rebooting.  Are they using Vista or something??  Anyway they believe the new software patch has solved the problem and the science should resume in earnest soon. One thing good for Mars lovers - when MRO calls the help desk - it doesn't end up in voice mail hell.

[vimeovid id="8267280"]

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignright size-thumbnail wp-image-1278" title="twis300" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/12/twis3003-150x150.jpg" alt="twis300" width="150" height="150" />Welcome to the premier of "This Week In Space With Miles O'Brien," a new show dedicated to keeping space lovers up to speed on the stories and issues making news off the planet.

This is Part 1 of 3, and features interviews with Augustine Commission member and former astronaut Leroy Chiao and SpaceX VP and former astronaut Ken Bowersox on the future of the U.S. manned spaceflight program.

		<item>
		<title>The Commercial Space Race Heats Up</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/21/the-commercial-space-race-heats-up/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Dec 2009 15:42:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Augustine Committee]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="augustine-committee"><![CDATA[Augustine Committee]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Barack Obama]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="barack-obama"><![CDATA[Barack Obama]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Commercial Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="commercial-space"><![CDATA[Commercial Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Constellation]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="constellation"><![CDATA[Constellation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Elon Musk]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="elon-musk"><![CDATA[Elon Musk]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Falcon 9]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="falcon-9"><![CDATA[Falcon 9]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="international-space-station"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iss"><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="mars"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Moon]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="moon"><![CDATA[Moon]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Politics]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="politics"><![CDATA[Politics]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[SpaceX]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="spacex"><![CDATA[SpaceX]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[SpaceX Dragon]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="spacex-dragon"><![CDATA[SpaceX Dragon]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1134</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1146" align="alignright" width="300" caption="DragonLab In Orbit.  Courtesy:  SpaceX"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1146" title="dragonlab_orbit_highres" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/dragonlab_orbit_highres.jpg?w=300" alt="DragonLab In Orbit.  Courtesy:  SpaceX" width="300" height="208" />[/caption]

Although the <a title="U.S. Human Spaceflight Plans Committee" href="http://www.nasa.gov/offices/hsf/home/index.html" target="_blank">Augustine Commission</a> did not offer up "recommendations" - it is clear they want NASA to focus on moving beyond low earth orbit - creating some space - if you will - for entrepreneurs to boldly go where only the government has gone before.

The man in the vanguard of this push is one Elon Musk - the PayPal multimillionaire - who now heads <a title="SpaceX" href="http://www.spacex.com/" target="_blank">SpaceX</a>. The California company won the NASA contract to build rockets that will deliver cargo to the International Space Station - but Musk hopes to do more than that - one day offering a ride to orbit for human beings.

SpaceX plans to test its Falcon 9 rocket and Dragon space capsule in early in 2010.

Former NASA astronaut <a title="NASA - Bowersox Biography" href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/bowersox.html" target="_blank">Ken Bowersox</a> is working on safety issues for SpaceX.  Watch below, or read the <a title="Ken Bowersox on 2009-12-11 at 12.13.doc" href="http://idisk.me.com/katobin/Public/" target="_blank">transcript</a> of my interview with him.

[vimeovid id="8266453"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=9a9493b2-0d8e-466c-9f71-ac88f179c2d9" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Politics]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="politics"><![CDATA[Politics]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[White House]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="white-house"><![CDATA[White House]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1131</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1151" align="alignright" width="300" caption="President Barak Obama and now-NASA Administrator Charlie Bolden meet at the White House, May 23. 2009.  Official White House photo by Pete Souza."]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1151" title="ObamaBolden 052309" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/obamabolden-052309.jpgmilesobrien/files/2009/12/ObamaBolden-0523091-300x196.jpg" alt="President Barak Obama and now-NASA Administrator Charlie Bolden meet at the White House, May 23. 2009.  Official White House photo by Pete Souza." width="300" height="196" />[/caption]

But just what kind of candle will U.S. astronauts be strapped onto in the post space shuttle era?

NASA Administrator Charlie Bolden dropped into the White House  the other day - and met with the President Obama to talk about what is next for the space agency.

We are told the meeting went well - that no decision has been made - but it will come soon - and when it does the President himself will make the announcement.

If you are a tea leaf reader - that last little tidbit bodes well for those of us who want the US to stay in the manned space racket.

Would Obama stand before the the nation and give a speech which says in essence "We choose NOT to go to the moon...because it is too hard and too expensive"? Unlikely, I think. Just my two cents here.

The White House space confab comes four months after the <a title="NASA - U.S. Human Spaceflight Plans Committee" href="http://www.nasa.gov/offices/hsf/home/index.html" target="_blank">Augustine Committee</a> shared its thoughts on what the US should - and should not do in the in the after shuttle years.

No matter which course Team Obama chooses - it means giving NASA about 3 billion dollars more a year - or stop sending humans to space.

So the Space Nation waits for word - hoping for a puff of white smoke from the conclave.

Let's begin with a word from one of the August members of the Augustine commission - former NASA astronaut, and our good friend <a title="Leroy Chiao Website" href="http://leroychiao.com/" target="_blank">Leroy Chiao</a>.   Watch below, or read the <a title="Leroy Chiao Interview" href="http://idisk.me.com/katobin/Public/lchiao on 2009-12-08 at 16.14.doc" target="_blank">transcript</a> of our interview.

[vimeovid id="8266296"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=d58443c9-70e5-4422-97e5-2e05317a93a4" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1138</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignright size-full wp-image-1141" title="384659main_Report_Widget" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/384659main_report_widget.jpg" alt="384659main_Report_Widget" width="226" height="170" />

Precious little has been said about the specifics of Charlie Bolden's Wednesday White House meeting with Obama on the future of human spaceflight.  But a "Science Insider" <a title="AAAS &quot;Science Insider&quot; Blog Post" href="http://blogs.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2009/12/exclusiveobama.html" target="_blank">blog post</a> over at AAAS has tongues wagging.  We can't vouch for the content...and the post is anonymously sourced...so who really knows?  It is worth a look-see, for your reading enjoyment.

But on Friday, the White House said no final decision has been made.

"The meeting with Bolden was informational, not decisional," said Nick Shapiro, White House spokesman.

"The President confirmed his commitment to human space exploration, and the goal of ensuring that the nation is on a sustainable path to achieving our aspirations in space," Shapiro said. "Against a backdrop of serious challenges with the existing program, the Augustine Committee has offered several key findings and a range of options for how the nation might improve its future human space flight activities. The two spoke about the Administrator's work at NASA and they also discussed the Augustine Committee's analysis."
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=09b95144-ea88-4d1f-aead-1c0e8a09d984" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-12-22 05:06:50</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[This could lead to a bumpy road, but maybe after we have adjusted we'll be on a more sustainable trajectory?
After the Challenger accident I thought it was a tremendous mistake to switch from full dependence on the Shuttle to trusting those "commercial" rockets. In hindsight, it was the right thing to do. Sure we lost a lot of business to Ariane, Dnepr, Long March, etc etc but people figured out that the cheap option was not always the best option.
Perhaps the Columbia accident will allow us to end another Government monopoly (one way or the other!!) and switch to commercial companies supplying rockets to get people into space. If we don't go with US commercial rockets we might be stuck with Russian rockets - if Ares does not turn out to be a lot easier and cheaper than it looks.
And in the meantime, Burt Rutan has showed us that an airdropped vehicle is truely practical, and might be cheaper and more reliable. They will take a while before they can put anything into orbit, but the path has been illuminated.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I work for a company that makes extensive commercial use of space technology. As I talk to some of the more knowledgeable people that work here, many of whom worked on the space program at NASA, I am struck by how many of them believe that the three orbiters are not going to be retired in 2010. The broad consensus is that as we get closer to the deadline in 2010, there will be a re-evaluation of the decision and an extension of the Shuttle program through the time a replacement is available.
I'm interested to know whether, from your perspective, you consider this just speculation or if there is some truth to it. What makes it so unreasonable?]]></wp:comment_content>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[At this late, late, date we could extend the Shuttle a few flights but not much. We have laid off workers, cancelled contracts, etc. We could fly the remaining few flights but insert some delays between flights. We could cobble together some spare parts. But the deed is done - and we will soon be sorry. Hopefully the US will one day again have the capability to do satellite rendezvous and repair, to do EVAs for Hubble type repairs. But we have decided that it is "too dangerous" and "too difficult". We will now rely on other countries (until about 2020 maybe) that do accept the danger and expense.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<item>
		<title>Captain Underpants and the Illusion of Security</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2009/12/30/captain-underpants-and-the-illusion-of-security/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 31 Dec 2009 03:00:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[airport]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="airport"><![CDATA[airport]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Al-Qaeda]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="al-qaeda"><![CDATA[Al-Qaeda]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Delta Air Lines]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="delta-air-lines"><![CDATA[Delta Air Lines]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[homeland security]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="homeland-security"><![CDATA[homeland security]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Janet Napolitano]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="janet-napolitano"><![CDATA[Janet Napolitano]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Politics]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="politics"><![CDATA[Politics]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Richard Reid]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="richard-reid"><![CDATA[Richard Reid]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[terror]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="terror"><![CDATA[terror]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[United States]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="united-states"><![CDATA[United States]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[US]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="us"><![CDATA[US]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[War on Terrorism]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="war-on-terrorism"><![CDATA[War on Terrorism]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1301</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>DESHAILES, GUADELOUPE - I doubt there are many people who would look forward to leaving this little piece of paradise. I am sitting on the deck of a sailboat anchored in the harbor of this quaint fishing village.</p>
<p>I just finished a hot croissant delivered by an enterprising young man plying the water on an inflatable dinghy (deftly prying Euros from my wallet with inflated prices - C’est la Vie!). The sun is shining, the breeze is steady and the temperature is 80°F.</p>
<p>What could be wrong with this picture?&nbsp; Nothing except what dutifully drops into my Kindle every morning via Whispernet (as opposed to the old Eastern Whisperjets...)</p>
<p>The absurd, inane, horse-out-of-the-barn response to the Christmas Day “Fruit of the Boom” Bomber-wannabe gives me even more reason to dread the trip back home.</p>
<p>My Kindle tells me my family and I will face long lines, lots of questions, pat down searches and an hour of lockdown time in our seats before landing. It is as if my ruler-brandishing first-grade teacher Sister Grace took over Delta Air Lines. “Books away - feet on the floor - hands on your desk - eyes straight ahead...”</p>
<p>It is brilliant thinking like the new seat arrest rule that should tell you a lot about our ill-conceived approach to thwarting terrorists who continue to find plane loads full of innocent Americans to be tempting targets. I don’t suppose future terrorists might try to light some portion of their clothing 61 minutes before landing do you?</p>
<p>What about the baby who needs a bottle or a passy on descent and is crying his lungs out?&nbsp; God help him, his mother and the rest of us...</p>
<p>We put the jerk in knee-jerk with the way we respond to threats.</p>
<p>Our Homeland Security Czarina Janet Napolitano tried to spin the whole thing into a triumph of our security apparatus. At least she didn’t get a “Nappy, you’re doin’ a heckuva a job!” from our Commander-in-Chief, but the Sunday talk show gaffe was one of those moments when the political Cuisinart jams on a big chunk of reality (it does, indeed, bite).</p>
<p>And of course we all know the Brief Bomber laid bare what I have suspected for a long time: that our no nail-clipper, no-hair gel, shoes-off, laptop-out security apparatus is little more than a Potemkin Village. It gives the appearance that we are doing something real&nbsp; - when all we are really doing is providing travelers a false sense of security - and often a real sense of frustration.</p>
<p>Let’s see: a young man embraces radical Islam and starts spewing some twisted, violent vitriol. His respected, influential father tells the CIA that he fears trouble and the US should revoke his son’s visa. The young man arrives at an an airport without any luggage and buys a one-way ticket to Detroit - with cash. And no one even arches an eyebrow? Come on people...you don’t have to be a security expert to know something was not right with that deal.</p>
<p>There was a time after 9/11 when I would routinely get selected for additional screening whenever I purchased a one-way ticket (which was fairly often given the vicissitudes of the TV News business).&nbsp; And I was using a corporate Amex card - flying an airline where I had logged a million miles. I used to grumble about it (silently, of course) because I assumed no future terrorist would be so stupid (or cheap) to buy only a one way ticket.</p>
<p>But, as I mentioned, I am no expert.</p>
<p>Here is what any moron can see as plain as day: our $40 billion dollar post-9/11 airline security net is a total joke - a White Elephant of epic (and potentially tragic) proportions.</p>
<p>The truth is the only aspect of our post 9/11 defense that has turned out to be 100% effective are the passengers themselves. Without really thinking about it we have become an airborne militia - all watching and ready to kick al Qaeda butt at the drop of... a pair of trousers. It began in Shanksville - it effectively thwarted the shoe-bomber - and now Captain Underpants.</p>
<p>Which brings me to my big worry: ever since Richard Reid tried to light up his sneakers, we have all had to remove our shoes before boarding. The logical conclusion in this illogical system: government sanctioned panty raids.</p>
<p>Your mother always told you to wear clean underwear.</p>
<p>Or maybe we should just get it over with and fly like the fat, old French guys I see strolling around this little cute Caribbean town: in Speedos and plastic sandals.</p>


<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=7560ffda-04a8-4989-a647-af5b2dc7bcc9" /></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Another, equally unsavory solution: would-be air commandos flying 'commando.'  That would sure challenge the see-though machine screeners - talk about 'TMI'!]]></wp:comment_content>

		<item>
		<title>Endeavour On the Move</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/05/endeavour-on-the-move/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 Jan 2010 18:58:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="endeavour"><![CDATA[Endeavour]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iss"><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="kennedy-space-center"><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>
