		<category domain="tag" nicename="kennedy-space-center"><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Launch pad]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="launch-pad"><![CDATA[Launch pad]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle-endeavour"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Vehicle Assembly Building]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="vehicle-assembly-building"><![CDATA[Vehicle Assembly Building]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1311</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1313" align="alignright" width="150" caption="The shuttle Endeavour in the Vehicle Assembly Building.  Source:  NASA"]<img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1313" title="Endeavour" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/endeavour1.jpg?w=150" alt="The shuttle Endeavour in the Vehicle Assembly Building.  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" />[/caption]

Happy New Year, everyone!

I'm back from my holiday Caribbean jaunt, and come Wednesday the shuttle Endeavour will be on the move as well - rolling out to launch pad 34A at the Kennedy Space Center.  First movement is currently scheduled for 4am EST (0900 GMT).  If you were there,  you would not have to worry about blinking and missing it.  The 3+ mile trip from the VAB to the pad typically takes about 8 hours with the massive crawler/transporter moving at literally snails pace.

Hard to believe there are only five scheduled flights remaining in the program.  This mission, STS-130, will be the next to last for Endeavour.   It's enough to make a hard-bitten veteran space reporter a little misty.

Watch for comprehensive coverage of this and all things space on our new weekly show, "This Week In Space," hosted by yours truly, over at<a title="Spaceflight Now" href="http://www.spaceflightnow.com" target="_blank"> Spacefight Now</a>.  And join us there for marathon live coverage of Endeavour's
launch, currently set for 4:39AM EST (0939 GMT) on February 7.  Just remember to set your alarm clock.
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=64d00032-580a-40db-a4a1-b7531c8c7773" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1319</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignright size-thumbnail wp-image-1320" title="twis300" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/01/twis300-150x150.jpg" alt="twis300" width="150" height="150" />The shuttle <a title="NASA - Shuttle Main Page" href="http://www.nasa.gov/shuttle" target="_blank">Endeavour</a> is "hard down at the pad," as they say at NASA.  Rollout commenced this morning at 4:13am EST and officially wrapped her trip at 10:37am EST.  It was a chilly 6+ hours of work for the team at KSC, who are not used to the sub-freezing temperatures and wind chill that hit the Space Coast this morning.  Now, work begins in earnest to prep the orbiter for launch on February 7 - Super Bowl Sunday, no less.  This mission will arguably be one of the most interesting of those remaining on the manifest...the astronauts will deliver and install Node 3, called Tranquility, and an attached cupola to the International Space Station.  After this mission, it all comes down to hauling some science instruments and a whole lot of spare parts up hill.  The finish line for the ISS is in sight!

In the mean time, our "This Week In Space" team is hard at work, evaluating stories and deciding what to include in our next show.  Right now, the plan includes a report on the hard work going on inside an old McDonalds at NASA Ames to reprocess lunar images that predate Apollo, an interview with Hubble spacewalker John Grunsfeld - who has just departed the astronaut corps and signed on as a bigwig at the Space Telescope Science Inst. (a/k/a Hubble Headquarters), and possibly a story on moonwalker and artist Alan Bean, who is just wrapping up an exhibition of his paintings at the Smithsonian.

And that's just for starters.  On the space beat, the fun never stops!  Watch this space for more on "This Week In Space."
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=81199f3a-041d-4511-aa51-714dcee879ef" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Hubble Hugger-In-Chief</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/08/hubble-hugger-in-chief/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 Jan 2010 19:11:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Astronomy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="astronomy"><![CDATA[Astronomy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Baltimore]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="baltimore"><![CDATA[Baltimore]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Hubble]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="hubble"><![CDATA[Hubble]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Hubble Space Telescope]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="hubble-space-telescope"><![CDATA[Hubble Space Telescope]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Institutions]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="institutions"><![CDATA[Institutions]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Observatories]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="observatories"><![CDATA[Observatories]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Optical and Infrared]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="optical-and-infrared"><![CDATA[Optical and Infrared]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Telescope Science Institute]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-telescope-science-institute"><![CDATA[Space Telescope Science Institute]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[STS-125]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="sts-125"><![CDATA[STS-125]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1325</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1326" align="alignright" width="150" caption="John Grunsfeld&#039;s favorite new Hubble image, the first taken with the new Wide Field Camera 3. Proves they didn&#039;t break the telescope!"]<img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1326" title="jupiter" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/jupiter.jpg?w=150" alt="Grunsfeld's favorite new Hubble Image, the first taken with the new Wide Field Camera 3. Proves they didn't break the telescope!" width="150" height="150" />[/caption]

I just finished a great Skype interview with Mr. Hubble Space Telescope himself, astronaut (ahem! now former astronaut)<a title="NASA - Grunsfeld Bio" href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/grunsfel.html" target="_blank"> John Grunsfeld</a>.  Fresh off last summer's hugely successful <a title="NASA STS-125" href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts125/main/index.html" target="_blank">STS-125</a> Hubble Servicing Mission, Grunsfeld has stepped down from the astronaut corps to join the<a title="Space Telescope Science Institute" href="http://www.stsci.edu/resources/" target="_blank"> Space Telescope Science Institute</a> in Baltimore, better known as Hubble Central.  He's pretty jazzed to be taking on a leadership role now that the newly refurbished Hubble has cranked into high gear for another go 'round re-writing the science textbooks.

We talked all about the challenges and triumphs of STS-125, reminisced a little about the pre-flight SCUBA dive I took with him in the big pool at the Johnson Space Center whike he was practicing on the Hubble mock-up they have there, and of course got his thoughts on Hubble's future.  You can watch the whole thing on our next edition of "This Week In Space."  A little taste...check out Grunsfeld's favorite image from the newly installed Wide Field Camera 3!
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=54ebbfa4-d1f0-4b18-9aed-b5b4d6dc1155" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Rise from the ashes?</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/rise-from-the-ashes/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Jan 2010 17:56:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="mars"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mars"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mars Phoenix]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mars-phoenix"><![CDATA[Mars Phoenix]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Missions]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="missions"><![CDATA[Missions]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[North Pole]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="north-pole"><![CDATA[North Pole]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Phoenix]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="phoenix"><![CDATA[Phoenix]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Phoenix Mars Lander]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="phoenix-mars-lander"><![CDATA[Phoenix Mars Lander]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Planet]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="planet"><![CDATA[Planet]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Spacecraft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="spacecraft"><![CDATA[Spacecraft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1331</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1332" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Phoenix Mars Lander.  Source:  NASA JPL/Univeristy of Arizona"]<img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1332" title="pml" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/pml.jpg?w=150" alt="Phoenix Mars Lander.  Source:  NASA JPL/Univeristy of Arizona" width="150" height="150" />[/caption]

Remember the <a title="Mars Phoenix - Univ. of Arizona" href="http://phoenix.lpl.arizona.edu/index.php" target="_blank">Mars Phoenix</a>?  Could it rise from the ashes -- or more accurately from a Dr. Zhivago like glaze of dry ice? <a title="NASA - Mars Phoenix" href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/phoenix/main/index.html" target="_blank"> NASA</a> last heard from Phoenix in November 2008.  The craft landed near the Martian North Pole about five months prior, logged a successful mission, and then died at the onset of winter.  Or did it?

Now that it is Spring (on Mars anyway), one of NASA's Martian orbiters will listen to see if Phoenix is still transmitting.  Who knows?  We may hear more from the first spacecraft to tweet.

Want to know more about ALL the news going on OFF the planet?  Join me for our new show "This Week In Space," powered by <a title="Spaceflight Now" href="http://www.spaceflightnow.com" target="_blank">Spaceflight Now</a>!

		<item>
		<title>The Spirit is willing, but the wheels are weak</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/the-spirit-is-willing-but-the-wheels-are-weak/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Jan 2010 19:23:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="mars"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mars"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mars Exploration Rover]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mars-exploration-rover"><![CDATA[Mars Exploration Rover]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mars rover]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mars-rover"><![CDATA[Mars rover]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Missions]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="missions"><![CDATA[Missions]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Regolith]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="regolith"><![CDATA[Regolith]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Spirit rover]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="spirit-rover"><![CDATA[Spirit rover]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1341</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1342" align="alignright" width="150" caption="The Mars rover &quot;Spirit.&quot;  Source:  NASA/JPL"]<img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1342" title="MER" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/mer.jpg?w=150" alt="The Mars rover &quot;Spirit.&quot;  Source:  NASA/JPL" width="150" height="150" />[/caption]

Six years after it first bounced onto the rusty regolith of Mars, the rover <a title="NASA - Mars Exploration Rovers" href="http://marsrover.nasa.gov/home/index.html" target="_blank">Spirit</a> is alive and still...well...spinning.

The rover is stuck in a sand trap and two wheels on it's right side remain "muerte."  The team is still trying to make the robot a <em>free</em> Spirit.  But they may soon have to settle for digging in deeper on one side, so the solar arrays will generate enough juice to keep it alive through the Martian winter -  which starts in May.

Want to know more about all the news on the space beat?  Join me for the new show "This Week In Space," powered by <a title="Spaceflight Now" href="http://www.spaceflightnow.com" target="_blank">Spaceflight Now</a>!

		<item>
		<title>Put Your Head Between Your Legs</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/langley-helicopter/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Jan 2010 14:20:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="aviation"><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="aviation"><![CDATA[Aviation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Crash test dummy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="crash-test-dummy"><![CDATA[Crash test dummy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Helicopter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="helicopter"><![CDATA[Helicopter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[ITunes]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="itunes"><![CDATA[ITunes]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Kevlar]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="kevlar"><![CDATA[Kevlar]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Langley Research Center]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="langley-research-center"><![CDATA[Langley Research Center]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Organ]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="organ"><![CDATA[Organ]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Virginia]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="virginia"><![CDATA[Virginia]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[YouTube]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="youtube"><![CDATA[YouTube]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1351</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1371" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Source:  NASA/Sean Smith"]<img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1371" title="helicopter" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/helicopter.jpg?w=150" alt="Source:  NASA/Sean Smith" width="150" height="150" />[/caption]

Check out what is either a scene from "Those Magnificent Men in their Flying Machines...or the Letterman show.

The place:  <a title="NASA Langley Research Center" href="http://www.nasa.gov/centers/langley/home/index.html" target="_blank">NASA's Langley Research Center</a> in Virginia.

The idea:  <a title="Helicopter Drop Test" href="http://www.nasa.gov/topics/aeronautics/features/helo-droptest.html" target="_blank">Drop a helicopter 35 feet</a> to see what happens.  The Army-donated bird was brimming with sensor and rigged up with a shock absorber made of honeycombed Kevlar.  Four crash dummies were strapped in, of which one had sensors in the torso that simulated internal organs (stop it!  I said <em>internal</em> organs!).

The Kevlar cushion was cooked up to protect astronauts in returning spacecraft - but engineers wanted to see it it could be a practical lifesaver for aviation as well.

The helicopter hit the ground at just over 53 miles per hour.  The dummies said their necks were hurting and they were calling their lawyers.

You can watch this story and much more on "This Week In Space."  Check us out!

Watch us:
<a title="Spaceflight Now" href="http://www.spaceflightnow.com" target="_blank">Spaceflight Now</a>

		<item>
		<title>Baby It&#039;s Cold Outside</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/baby-its-cold-outside/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Jan 2010 14:28:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Animals]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="animals"><![CDATA[Animals]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Endangered species]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="endangered-species"><![CDATA[Endangered species]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="kennedy-space-center"><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="kennedy-space-center"><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Turtle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="turtle"><![CDATA[Turtle]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1353</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="NASA Kennedy Space Center" href="http://www.nasa.gov/centers/kennedy/home/index.html" target="_blank"></a>

[caption id="attachment_1374" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Source:  NASA/Amanda Diller"]<a><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1374" title="turtlesmall" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/turtlesmall.jpg?w=150" alt="Source:  NASA/Amanda Diller" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

NASA's Kennedy Space Center can be a pretty wild place, literally.  The launch pads sit amid the Merritt Island Wildlife Refuge.  All kinds of rare and endangered species live there, and they just got some unexpected company.

About <a title="http://www.nasa.gov/centers/kennedy/news/seaturtles.html" href="http://www.nasa.gov/centers/kennedy/news/seaturtles.html" target="_blank">300 loggerhead turtles </a>meandered into a lagoon at the Cape, apparently stunned by the unusually cold water off the Florida Coast.  Wildlife agents and scientists organized a rescue mission.  The turtles were checked out and shipped to a warm place inland, where they will stay until the weather turns for the better.

<span style="font-size:small;">Check out "This Week In Space" for more like this!
</span><strong><span style="font-size:x-large;"><span style="font-size:small;"> </span></span></strong>

		<item>
		<title>Limping Home</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/limping-home/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Jan 2010 14:33:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Asteroid]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="asteroid"><![CDATA[Asteroid]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Earth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="earth"><![CDATA[Earth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Hayabusa]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="hayabusa"><![CDATA[Hayabusa]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[ITunes]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="itunes"><![CDATA[ITunes]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Japan]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="japan"><![CDATA[Japan]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="japan-aerospace-exploration-agency"><![CDATA[Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space debris]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-debris"><![CDATA[Space debris]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Spacecraft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="spacecraft"><![CDATA[Spacecraft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Twitter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="twitter"><![CDATA[Twitter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[YouTube]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="youtube"><![CDATA[YouTube]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1355</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-size:small;"><span style="font-size:small;"> </span></span>

[caption id="attachment_1380" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Source:  JAXA"]<img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1380" title="hayabusa" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/hayabusa.jpg?w=150" alt="Source:  JAXA" width="150" height="150" />[/caption]

On the theme of the "Little Spacecraft that Could," we bring you the amazing seven year odyssey of Japan's <a title="JAXA - Hayabusa" href="http://www.jaxa.jp/projects/sat/muses_c/index_e.html" target="_blank">Hayabusa</a> - which is Japanese for Peregrin Falcon.

Three years, late, after a fuel leak and a cascade of failures that should have made it a piece of space junk, Hayabusa is on the home stretch -- hopefully bring back some dust from an asteroid.

The spacecraft has a novel propulsion system, which failed, but the ground team was able to rig up a makeshift way to generate thrust by using operative components of different engines.  If all goes well, the Falcon should feel the gravitational pull of Earth this June.<strong><span style="font-size:small;"><span style="font-size:small;"> </span></span></strong>

<strong> </strong>Follow Hayabusa and lots of other space stuff on "This Week In Space."

Watch us:
<a title="Spaceflight Now" href="http://www.spaceflightnow.com" target="_blank">Spaceflight Now</a>
<a title="Vimeo Space Flight Now" href="http://vimeo.com/user2505907" target="_blank">Vimeo</a>
<a title="You Tube - Spaceflight Now" href="http://www.youtube.com/user/spaceflightnow" target="_blank">You Tube</a>
<a title="iTunes" href="http://itunes.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/browserRedirect?url=itms%253A%252F%252Fitunes.apple.com%252FWebObjects%252FMZStore.woa%252Fwa%252FviewPodcast%253Fid%253D348142944" target="_blank">iTunes</a>

		<item>
		<title>Kepler Exoplanets</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/kepler-exoplanets/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Jan 2010 14:41:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Astronomy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="astronomy"><![CDATA[Astronomy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Earth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="earth"><![CDATA[Earth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Extrasolar planet]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="extrasolar-planet"><![CDATA[Extrasolar planet]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Gas giant]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="gas-giant"><![CDATA[Gas giant]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Hot Jupiter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="hot-jupiter"><![CDATA[Hot Jupiter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Jupiter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="jupiter"><![CDATA[Jupiter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Kepler Mission]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="kepler-mission"><![CDATA[Kepler Mission]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Planet]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="planet"><![CDATA[Planet]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1357</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-size:small;"> </span>

[caption id="attachment_1383" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Kepler Space Telescope"]<img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1383" title="Kepler" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/kepler.jpg?w=150" alt="Kepler Space Telescope" width="150" height="150" />[/caption]

If Hubble is Benjamin Button, the<a title="Kepler Space Telescope" href="http://kepler.nasa.gov/" target="_blank"> Kepler Space Telescope </a>might be called Goldilocks -  as it is designed to find the planets that are just right for harboring life as we know it.  And the Kepler team has rolled out its first batch of discoveries.

Five planets in all - none like Earth - but, hey, it's a start.  The team says they are "hot Jupiters," gas giants orbiting very close to their suns.  So how hot is it on these planets?  Hotter than molten lava - or even a New York subway platform in August.

Check out this story and more on what's going on off the planet on "This Week In Space."

Watch us:

<a title="Spaceflight Now" href="http://www.spaceflightnow.com" target="_blank">Spaceflight Now</a>

		<item>
		<title>Hubble Hugger-In-Chief</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/hubble-hugger-in-chief-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Jan 2010 15:47:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Baltimore]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="baltimore"><![CDATA[Baltimore]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Hubble]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="hubble"><![CDATA[Hubble]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Hubble Space Telescope]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="hubble-space-telescope"><![CDATA[Hubble Space Telescope]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[John Grunsfeld]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="john-grunsfeld"><![CDATA[John Grunsfeld]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[John M. Grunsfeld]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="john-m-grunsfeld"><![CDATA[John M. Grunsfeld]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="lyndon-b-johnson-space-center"><![CDATA[Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Telescope Science Institute]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-telescope-science-institute"><![CDATA[Space Telescope Science Institute]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[STS-125]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="sts-125"><![CDATA[STS-125]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1359</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-size:small;"> </span>

[caption id="attachment_1391" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Hubble Space Telescope.  Source:  NASA"]<img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1391" title="hubble" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/hubble.jpg?w=150" alt="Hubble Space Telescope.  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" />[/caption]

If you are anything like me, you were on the edge of your chair last summer, watching the crew of the shuttle Atlantis grind out five marathon spacewalks for a <a title="STS-125" href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts125/main/index.html" target="_blank">final servicing mission</a> to the Hubble Space Telescope.

<span style="font-size:small;">The Atlantis crew really hit it out of the park, installing some new instruments, and resurrecting some old ones that had seemed broken beyond repair.
</span>

<span style="font-size:small;">The lead spacewalker was <a title="NASA Bio - John Grunsfeld" href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/grunsfel.html" target="_blank">John Grunsfeld</a>, on his third Hubble Servicing Mission.  I had the good fortune to do an unique underwater interview with him in the run-up to STS-125, as he practiced some of his tasks in the pool at the Johnson Space Center in Houston.  I even tried my hand with the pistol grip tool...that's NASA-speak for an electric screwdriver...and believe me they just make it look easy.
</span>

<span style="font-size:small;">So now Hubble is churning out great images like this - and should be for another decade...
</span>

<span style="font-size:small;">But what now Columbus? What does a Hubble Hugger do for a next act?
</span>

<span style="font-size:small;">The obvious choice: join the team at Hubble Headquarters.  That's the <a href="www.stsci.edu">Space Telescope Science Institute </a>in Baltimore.  Grunsfeld - who has a PhD in physics - is the new deputy director.  I Skyped  him the other day to hear more about that final repair mission, and where he and where Hubble go from here.  Read the t<a title="Grunsfeld Transcript" href="http://idisk.me.com/katobin-Public/Grunsfeld Transcript.doc" target="_blank">ranscript</a>, or watch below:</span>

<span style="font-size:small;">[vimeovid id="8762083"]
</span>
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=17bd600d-b9bc-4d53-b0ba-12d6f964156b" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<item>
		<title>&quot;This Week in Space&quot; Mailbag</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/this-week-in-space-mailbag/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Jan 2010 15:50:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Viewer Mail]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="viewer-mail"><![CDATA[Viewer Mail]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1361</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-size:small;"> </span><span style="font-size:small;"><strong><img class="alignright size-thumbnail wp-image-1363" title="twis300" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/01/twis3002-150x150.jpg" alt="twis300" width="150" height="150" /></strong>We got lots of feedback on the first edition of "This Week In Space," and we thought we'd share some of it with you.  For the most part we had a real outpouring of support, and for that we thank you.  A few examples...</span>

Del Boyles emailed in "This is exactly what the (Space Junkie) doctor ordered and provides the missing link to important news that is omitted by the existing media.  Keep 'em coming!"

"Freehawk" tweeted to us "<span><span>Enjoyed Episode one, good production, interesting content and fast paced. May the news be prolific for you in the New Year."  AMEN TO THAT Freehawk.</span></span>

And Mike Kropf typed "I plan to watch on the web, every week.  Now just get Mr. Obama and the boys in Congress to watch as well, and things may just work out!!"  HOSANNA TO THAT ONE, Mike.

We got some constructive ideas that we plan to take to heart.  Jason Legere emailed "I would love to see an occasional look into the space efforts of countries other than the US....it would be interesting to see the gamut of space research and activity around the globe."

And to be fair, you folks sent in a few zingers as well.

Mark Briceno emailed "I have always liked Miles as a reporter, so please do not take offense: Miles should dial down the jokes. "  Oh, no offense taken, Mark - but we have added your email to our spam catcher...oh - sorry that was a joke too!

And then there is my personal favorite:
This tweet from QuantumG, who I might add had a number of pointed things to say to us...
" I have no idea who the "blank" Miles O'Brien is... to me that's the name of a character in Star Trek."

You are by no means the first to confuse me with Chief O'Brien, Quantum G! And who the "bleep" are you, anyway?
<span style="font-size:small;"><strong> </strong></span>

<span style="font-size:small;"><strong> </strong></span>

<strong> </strong>

<strong> </strong> <span style="font-size:small;">If you are a viewer of "This Week In Space," we'd like to hear from you too.
</span>

<span style="font-size:small;"><strong> </strong></span>

		<item>
		<title>McMoon and the Lunar Orbiter Image Recovery Project</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/mcmoon-and-the-lunar-orbiter-image-recovery-project/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Jan 2010 22:15:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Apollo 11]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="apollo-11"><![CDATA[Apollo 11]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Astronomy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="astronomy"><![CDATA[Astronomy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Earth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="earth"><![CDATA[Earth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[ElonMusk]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="elonmusk"><![CDATA[ElonMusk]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Lunar Orbiter Image Recovery Project]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="lunar-orbiter-image-recovery-project"><![CDATA[Lunar Orbiter Image Recovery Project]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Moon]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="moon"><![CDATA[Moon]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Moon]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="moon"><![CDATA[Moon]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Solar System]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="solar-system"><![CDATA[Solar System]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1410</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-size:x-large;"><span style="font-size:small;">

[caption id="attachment_1416" align="alignright" width="148" caption="Source:  Lunar Orbiter Image Recovery Project/NASA Ames"]<img class="size-medium wp-image-1416" title="first-earth-from-moon" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/first-earth-from-moon.jpg?w=148" alt="Source:  Lunar Orbiter Image Recovery Project/NASA Ames" width="148" height="300" />[/caption]

Whether they carry a badge signed by Charlie Bolden or Elon Musk, rocket scientists are genetically hardwired to obsess about the future.  In the course of turning their visions into reality, they sometimes forget the importance of history. </span></span>

<span style="font-size:x-large;"><span style="font-size:small;">Such was the case when they lost those high quality tapes of the Apollo 11 moonwalk - how the heck did that happen?</span></span>

<span style="font-size:x-large;"><span style="font-size:small;">There was another near historical tragedy involving yet another moon mission - but the day was saved by and <a title="Lunar Orbiter Image Recovery Project" href="http://www.moonviews.com/" target="_blank">unlikely team</a>, working in an unlikely place.</span></span>

<span style="font-size:x-large;"><span style="font-size:small;">
</span> </span>
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=6f5202d5-620c-4dee-8c5d-bd5fca91e66a" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"> </span></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>

		<item>
		<title>Space Rocks</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/space-rocks/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Jan 2010 22:23:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="endeavour"><![CDATA[Endeavour]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iss"><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Moon]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="moon"><![CDATA[Moon]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1408</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1420" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Longbow and Zambo"]<img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1420" title="Longbow and Zambo" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/01/Longbow-and-Zambo-150x110.jpg" alt="Longbow and Zambo" width="150" height="110" />[/caption]

The<a title="Tranquility Node" href="http://www.nasa.gov/centers/kennedy/stationpayloads/tranquility.html" target="_blank"> Tranquility Node</a> will offer station keepers the best view of earth from inside the outpost...by far.

It is has a large cupola - with big 80 centimeter - 31 inch - porthole surrounded  half dozen trapezoid windows.  Built by the European Space Agency - this room with a view will also serve as a control tower for robot arm operations.

And it will have a special plaque somewhere in the mullions.

On it: some moon rocks collected by Neil Armstrong on July 20th 1969 - and carried to the top of Mount Everest by former astronaut <a title="NASA - Scott Parazynski Bio" href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/parazyns.html" target="_blank">Scott Parazynski</a> on May 20th of 2009. Parazynski <a title="Pearlman article - space.com" href="http://www.space.com/news/cs-100106-moon-everest-space-rocks.html" target="_blank">gave the moon rocks</a> - along with a piece of Everest to shuttle commander <a title="NASA - George Zamka Bio" href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/zamka.html" target="_blank">George Zamka</a> in Houston on January 6th. "Zambo" is one overqualified rock courier to be sure.

[vimeovid id="8770332"] ]]></content:encoded>

		<title>We have a donnybrook here!</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/we-have-a-donnybrook-here/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Jan 2010 22:37:56 +0000</pubDate>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[White House]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="white-house"><![CDATA[White House]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1404</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignright size-full wp-image-1425" title="384659main_Report_Widget" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/01/384659main_Report_Widget2.jpg" alt="384659main_Report_Widget" width="226" height="170" />Of course that is what the space world is hoping the Obama Administration will do by the end of this month...light the candle on NASA's next chapter in piloted space exploration...

Now if someone tells you they know what the White House is going to do - they are probably lying - unless that someone happens to be the President, the President's Science Advisor - or NASA administrator Charlie Bolden. We do know this - the President will deliver his State of the Union address and then roll out his budget by the first week in February.   Surely we will know something concrete by then.

Safe to say Obama is going to sanction more international partnerships in space - a greater role for the private sector to build rockets - and a a mandate that NASA push the exploration envelope...So where does that leave your favorite space vehicle? Well if it is the shuttle - headed for the Smithsonian - don't hold your breath for a reprieve for the orbiters...If you are a fan on the <a title="NASA - Constellation" href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/constellation/main/index.html" target="_blank">Constellation</a> plan - the Ares 1 - a trip back to the moon- you have some friends in Congress.

Late last year, Alabama Senator <a title="Senator Richard Sheby" href="http://shelby.senate.gov/public/" target="_blank">Richard Shelby</a> engineered a rules change that requires congressional approval of any big change to human exploration plans. As Keith Jackson might say - "Who Nellie - we have a donnybrook here." So stay tuned.
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=6c8081a6-2c71-40d6-9ac3-2b9ded0e5454" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Shuttle Grab Bag</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/shuttle-grab-bag/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Jan 2010 22:44:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Crew Equipment Interface Test]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="crew-equipment-interface-test"><![CDATA[Crew Equipment Interface Test]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Discovery]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="discovery"><![CDATA[Discovery]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="endeavour"><![CDATA[Endeavour]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iss"><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="kennedy-space-center"><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="kennedy-space-center"><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Discovery]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle-discovery"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Discovery]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle-endeavour"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Vehicle Assembly Building]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="vehicle-assembly-building"><![CDATA[Vehicle Assembly Building]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1406</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1429" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Source:  NASA"]<img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1429" title="endeavour at the pad" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/endeavour-at-the-pad.jpg?w=150" alt="Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" />[/caption]

It will be a sad nostalgic year for the space shuttle team - every milestone toward launch - will also be one more step toward the end of an era.

The shuttle <a title="STS-130" href="http://www.nasa.gov/shuttle" target="_blank">Endeavour</a> headed out to launch pad 39A at the Kennedy Space Center last week.  She's currently undergoing final preps for launch on a mission to deliver and install Tranquility - the third and final node of the space station. But all is not <em>tranquil</em> for this station component - the ammonia lines that connect Tranquility to the station cooling system failed a pressurization test.  Apparently it is a fundamental design flaw, one team is working on a redesign that will be sent up to station later.  But for now - engineers are now welding together some shorter hoses in an effort to jury rig a fix.

Launch is targeted for Feburary 7, but don't write that one in pen.

In the mean time, crews moved the the big external fuel tank that will power Discovery into orbit in March into the Vehicle Assembly Building where it will be mated with the solid rocket boosters and the orbiter.

And Discovery’s crew was at the Cape this week for what’s called a Crew Equipment Interface Test – it is the last time they can lay their hands on some flight hardware before they head off on their supply run to the station.
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=0eaea3de-2582-4980-be3d-366957f31429" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Falcon 9 Test Fire</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/falcon-9-test-fire/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Jan 2010 23:29:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Cape Canaveral]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="cape-canaveral"><![CDATA[Cape Canaveral]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Commercial Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="commercial-space"><![CDATA[Commercial Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Elon Musk]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="elon-musk"><![CDATA[Elon Musk]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Falcon 1]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="falcon-1"><![CDATA[Falcon 1]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Falcon 9]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="falcon-9"><![CDATA[Falcon 9]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="international-space-station"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[SpaceX]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="spacex"><![CDATA[SpaceX]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1434</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-size:x-large;"><span style="font-size:small;"><span> </span></span></span>

[caption id="attachment_1435" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Source:  SpaceX"]<img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1435" title="Falcon9 on Pad" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/falcon9-on-pad.jpg?w=150" alt="Source:  SpaceX" width="150" height="150" />[/caption]

Deep in the heart of Texas - a big step on the road to sending privately built spacecraft to the International Space Station.

Space Exploration Technologies, or <a title="SpaceX" href="http://www.spacex.com/" target="_blank">SpaceX</a>, ran a full duration test of the second stage motor for its Falcon 9 rocket.  Looks good to me - lots of noise, fire and smoke - and the company confirms the motor did pass the test.

Now they can start packing it up and shipping it off to Cape Canaveral.  SpaceX founder Elon Musk says the test launch will happen there one to two months after the motor is delivered.  The company has a 1.5 billion dollar NASA contract to build a spacecraft that can deliver cargo to the station.  Takes the Fed out of Fed-ex I suppose...

<span style="font-size:x-large;"><span style="font-size:small;">
</span></span>

		<wp:comment_author_email>apps+63131344600.1257481200.2e3ae47b8239f14c271c095c175b2e87@proxymail.facebook.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.facebook.com/people/Dewi-Morgan/1257481200</wp:comment_author_url>

		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-01-19 00:07:37</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[It's a great show, the fluff and sensationalism makes it interesting, but it needs a little *fact* to back it up.

As well as joking that it's hotter than a subway, it'd be nice to get an actual approximate temperature.

As well as joking about how the dummies felt, it'd be nice to say whether the test results for the honeycombed cushion stood a chance of being used as a protective device.

Possibly just as good - nay, even better - would be a scrolling tagline with the hard data and URLs to more info about each article, like project websites, etc, so you wouldn't have to second-guess what data people actually want(*). The segment is, amongst other things, meant to make people want to know more about the industry, and be interested in current projects, right? So make it easy for them!

(* But, pro tip to help with the guessing - wherever you use a simile, like "five times as hot as the sun" etc: you want to be giving an actual measurement first, like "three thousand degrees C", then give the simile as a "human figure" afterwards).]]></wp:comment_content>

		<item>
		<title>Station Keeping</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/24/station-keeping/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 24 Jan 2010 19:30:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="international-space-station"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Jeffrey Williams]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="jeffrey-williams"><![CDATA[Jeffrey Williams]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Low Earth orbit]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="low-earth-orbit"><![CDATA[Low Earth orbit]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Poisk]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="poisk"><![CDATA[Poisk]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Soyuz]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="soyuz"><![CDATA[Soyuz]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1496</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-size:small;"> </span>

[caption id="attachment_1188" align="alignright" width="150" caption="International Space Station.  Source:  NASA"]<span> <img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1188" title="ISS" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/12/ISS-150x150.jpg" alt="International Space Station.  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></span>[/caption]

Sometimes its just nice to get out of the house - isn't it? Not so easy if you happen to be sealed up in some aluminum cans in low earth orbit...

That said,  station keepers  Max Suraev and Jeff Williams took the Soyuz for a spin around the Space Station the other day - they were careful not to exceed the speed limit - 17,500 miles an hour - as they parked at the new Poisk docking port. But that was not their number one task - they are vexed by a clogged potty - apparently too much calcium in their urine.  You know what they say - too much calcium - and <em>your-in</em> trouble.
[youtubevid id="dWjqIvAli_U&amp;start=65"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=282145ce-0ba9-47d7-a475-f248b9192e5c" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[32]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
		<item>
		<title>Fourth Rock from the Sun</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/24/fourth-rock-from-the-sun/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 24 Jan 2010 19:37:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[HiRISE]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="hirise"><![CDATA[HiRISE]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="mars"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mars"><![CDATA[Mars]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mars-reconnaissance-orbiter"><![CDATA[Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[North Pole]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="north-pole"><![CDATA[North Pole]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Phoenix]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="phoenix"><![CDATA[Phoenix]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Phoenix Mars Lander]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="phoenix-mars-lander"><![CDATA[Phoenix Mars Lander]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Spirit rover]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="spirit-rover"><![CDATA[Spirit rover]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Spirit rover]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="spirit-rover"><![CDATA[Spirit rover]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[University of Arizona]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="university-of-arizona"><![CDATA[University of Arizona]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1465</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1466" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Source:  Hubble Space Telescope"]<span><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1466" title="Mars_Hubble" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/mars_hubble.jpg?w=150" alt="Source:  Hubble Space Telescope" width="150" height="150" /></span>[/caption]

Now to our planetary neighbor - where one of NASA's orbiters has its ears cupped listening for an unlikely call from the<a href="http://phoenix.lpl.arizona.edu/index.php" target="_blank"> Mars Phoenix lander</a>.Phoenix, you'll recall,  landed near the North pole in May 2008 sampled the soil until until winter in November.  Now that it is spring - the Phoenix team cannot resist seeing if their baby survived. No one's betting on it...but if they get lucky they might have to rename it Timex - you know, takes a licking...keeps on ticking.  Sorry about the dated reference kids.

In warmer Martian climes - the <a href="http://marsrover.nasa.gov/home/index.html" target="_blank">Spirit</a> Rover moved a tad - or maybe a scosh this week. Good - but not enough to make its way out of that sand trap its mired in. The Spirt team has not given up yet - but soon they may have top  focus on tilting the rovers - so its solar panels can better catch the low winter sun.

And here's a cool <a href="http://hirise.lpl.arizona.edu/PSP_007962_2635" target="_blank">postcard</a> from Mars...showing the forest...or so it seems.  This unusual image comes from the HiRISE camera on the Mars Reconnaisance Orbiter.  Apparently it is a dune field - and those tree like thingies - dust kicked up by dry ice.

And check out <a href="http://hirise.lpl.arizona.edu/ESP_016036_1370" target="_blank">this one</a>.  Looks like a bull dozer has been busy up there - the wind makes this pattern in the dunes.  Those are boulders littering the valleys between.  Desktop wallpaper anyone?

And listen up shutterbugs - you wanna try your hand at interplanetary photography?  The team at the University of Arizona has started a new program called "Pick Pixels on Mars."  just point your browser <a href="http://www.uahirise.org/suggest/" target="_blank">here</a> - and suggest a site - you might end up with an enviable photo credit.

<span style="font-size:small;">
</span>

<span style="font-size:small;"> </span>

[youtubevid id="dWjqIvAli_U&amp;start=103"]

		<title>Wanna Buy a Shuttle?</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/24/wanna-buy-a-shuttle/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 24 Jan 2010 19:45:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Smithsonian Institution]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="smithsonian-institution"><![CDATA[Smithsonian Institution]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Discovery]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle-discovery"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Discovery]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle-endeavour"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Wal Mart]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="wal-mart"><![CDATA[Wal Mart]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1474</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-size:small;"> </span>

[caption id="attachment_1313" align="alignright" width="150" caption="The shuttle Endeavour in the Vehicle Assembly Building.  Source:  NASA"] <span><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1313" title="Endeavour" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/01/Endeavour1-150x150.jpg" alt="The shuttle Endeavour in the Vehicle Assembly Building.  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></span>[/caption]

NASA is taking a cue from Wal Mart offering  the low price - always...the agency slashed the price to <a href="http://www.collectspace.com/news/news-011510a.html" target="_blank">acquire an orbiter for public display</a>.

They were asking 42 million bucks but just lowered the price to just south of 29 million - not including taxes title and dealer prep. Actually you can't buy the orbiters when they are done flying - you are just paying for the shipping - piggyback on a custom 747. The higher price included the cost of safeing the vehicles - meaning cleaning out all those nasty, volatile and cancer causing chemcials. But now NASA says it will pay for that. The buyers still have to figure out how to get the orbiters from the nearest airport big enough for that 747 - to the museum - no dismantling allowed.

The Smithsonian has already claimed Discovery.   A decision on where the others end up will come this summer - what does an orbiter do to keep busy in retirement?  - play "shuttle-board" of course...

[youtubevid id="dWjqIvAli_U&amp;start=408"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=1b9d8eaa-30a0-4b5d-a535-57d6a78a485d" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"> </span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Alan Bean - Moonwalker and Artist</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/24/alan-bean-moonwalker-and-artist/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 24 Jan 2010 19:47:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1469</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight:normal;"><span style="font-size:x-large;"><span style="font-size:small;"> </span></span></span>

[caption id="attachment_1470" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Alan Bean.   Source:  NASA"]  <span><span><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1470" title="AlanBean-crop" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/01/alanbean-crop.jpg?w=150" alt="Alan Bean.   Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></span></span>[/caption]

You best not have a frozen budget if you want to buy a painting from the only artist who has walked on the moon. His name is <a href="http://www.alanbeangallery.com/" target="_blank">Alan Bean</a> - and this past summer I was lucky enough to get a tour of his tour de force exhibit at the Air and Space Museum in Washington D.C..

[youtubevid id="dWjqIvAli_U&amp;start=202"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=b0d7ca63-1b06-4792-a7f9-99583e9646b8" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Endeavour Prepares for Launch</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/24/endeavour-prepares-for-launch/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 24 Jan 2010 19:53:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="endeavour"><![CDATA[Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Houston]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="houston"><![CDATA[Houston]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="international-space-station"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="iss"><![CDATA[ISS]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="kennedy-space-center"><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="kennedy-space-center"><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle-endeavour"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Terminal Countdown Demonstration Test]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="terminal-countdown-demonstration-test"><![CDATA[Terminal Countdown Demonstration Test]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Tranquility]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="tranquility"><![CDATA[Tranquility]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1463</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-size:small;"> </span>

[caption id="attachment_1429" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Source:  NASA"]<span> <img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1429" title="endeavour at the pad" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/01/endeavour-at-the-pad-150x150.jpg" alt="Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></span>[/caption]

It was Launch Day - without the fire and rumble - this week at the Kennedy Space Center.

The crew of <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/shuttle" target="_blank">STS-130</a> streaked in from Houston on their supersonic T-38's - donned  their Launch and re-entry - or pumpkin suits - and then when through the motions of launch day. The dress rehearsal is called the Terminal Countdown Demonstration Test, or TCDT.  The exercise ends with a simulated launch pad abort - and later a spin in an armored personnel carrier.

As for the vehicle that will take them to space - Endeavour is doing fine - although the piece of the space station that sits in her trunk - the Tranquility node - is still giving the shuttle team a mental workout. Cooling lines that carry ammonia failed a leak test a few weeks ago. The team is working to improve the hose design - while also beefing up and piecing together some smaller sections. They are calling the result "Frankenhose."  The shuttlers are still hoping for a February 7th launch.
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=0646c923-5f53-4f81-9836-ddbe5c55956a" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="skype"><![CDATA[Skype]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[SpaceX]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="spacex"><![CDATA[SpaceX]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=1460</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1146" align="alignright" width="150" caption="DragonLab In Orbit.  Courtesy:  SpaceX"] <span><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1146" title="dragonlab_orbit_highres" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/12/dragonlab_orbit_highres-150x150.jpg" alt="DragonLab In Orbit.  Courtesy:  SpaceX" width="150" height="150" /></span>[/caption]

Even though the <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/offices/hsf/home/index.html" target="_blank">Augustine Commission </a>did not pick a vehicle or a destination  when it issued its report on the future of human Spaceflight to Obama -  it was clear from reading the tea leaves in their report that the Augies liked the idea of entrepreneurs building rockets for trips to low earth orbit.

But another group of gray beards that noses around NASA - the <a href="http://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/oer/asap/index.html" target="_blank">Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel</a> - this week lowered the boom on this notion - ASAP said anything other than the plan of record - specifically the the Ares 1 rocket - would be no faster, no cheaper - and less safe than, say the Falcon 9 rocket, being built by <a href="http://www.spacex.com/" target="_blank">SpaceX</a>. I caught up with SpaceX CEO Elon Musk this week via Skype - he was fuming over that report.

[youtubevid id="ifwFa5DtIps&amp;start=90"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=b4ec03b0-3d5c-4a82-a819-91bc6cc74d6d" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>musk-fires-back</wp:post_name>

		<title>Obama Ponders the Future of Human Space Flight</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/01/24/obama-ponders-the-future-of-human-space-flight/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 24 Jan 2010 19:59:29 +0000</pubDate>
