		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[The kids and I love your weekly.

As an Aerospace Engineer, I really don't think we should have Mars as a goal or destination for humans.  Occupying NASA with the big mission just occupies a good organization which should be working the developments that make the Space industry viable in the economic sense (nano structure research paid for, bio research paid upfront, etc).   Elon knows he can make $$ with his endeavors - maybe Solar Power for his cars? But the point is, I really like the Augustine Panel input and I can see that it is in the proposed plan.  The point I want to make is that the goal appears to be much smarter than can be answered easily - let me take a try at it - our (NASAs) next destination is "to develop and sustain the technologies to move NASA and Space industry forward - goals will be performanced based,for example, the VASMR project"... and for private industry "Space is now open for business" (oops, that's your input)....

I'm not inspired with going to the moon or mars (big yawn) if we can't maintain it for the kids.  On another note, The X-37B is cute as hell, I can't wait to see it ....land.. (you can't see it launch).  That OTV looks like it has big tanks!  When this things lands, be prepared to be inspired!  Be prepared for all NASA supporters to say "hey there Mr. USAF, we want one of those!"]]></wp:comment_content>

		<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>172.20.1.235</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2010-02-28 04:25:41</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-02-28 09:25:41</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I'd have to check some charts; however, I believe the RTLS Powered Pitch Around occurs at about 250 nautical miles downrange and 430,000 feet up.

This maneuver marks the end of the Fuel Dissipation phase and begins the start of the Flyback phase.

By 400 nautical miles downrange the mated vehicle has ceased its "backward" motion and is still about 280,000 feet up.

So, the "flying supersonic backwards into your own rocket plume" part begins outside of the sensible atmosphere (recall that Entry Interface is at 400,000 feet) and is over before the static pressure exceeds 0.000147 lb/ft2.

If RTLS is not a viable abort mode then folks have certainly spent a lot of precious resources building, testing, maintaining, training to, developing mission unique I-Loads, Cue-cards, etc … for the capability.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA["That said, I hope we don’t lose too much of our expertise." Well, there in lies the rub. NASA seems more than willing to throw that expertise away. The same thing happened when Apollo was canceled. Why should anyone want to go into science/engineering today. These people are not valued and they are viewed as disposable. You are better off with an MBA, a bean counter degree, or a (ugh) law degree. Teachers are not valued either. Our business leaders and politicians usually think of the short term, occasionally the mid-term and never the long term. Depending on business to advance us into space is a pipe dream. Who has been building our rockets all along? They won't do anything really important unless we pour money down their rat holes. You were inspired by NASA and Apollo as were a generation of scientist and engineers. Where has that inspiration been over the last 20 years. Where is it in the current (snicker) plan? If Constellation had been funded we might have been close. Now we throw it all away ($9 billion + $2.5 to cancel the contracts) plus the time invested. Now we start over with some company that is just a hobby. How much money are we going to throw down that rat hole to find out that it is over budget and behind schedule? Manned flight is a lot more complex than sending a bunch of MREs to the ISS. NASA will lose its institutional memory again, just like auto companies do on a regular basis. That is why we have cars that go into sudden acceleration. Worse, we will have decisions made on the basis of expense and profit. However, the worse thing about all of this is the complete lack of vision. How do you expect to inspire future scientists and engineers without a vision.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<item>
		<title>The late, great Robert McCall....</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/02/28/the-late-great-robert-mccall/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 28 Feb 2010 15:43:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[2001: A Space Odyssey]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="2001-a-space-odyssey"><![CDATA[2001: A Space Odyssey]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Apollo]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="apollo"><![CDATA[Apollo]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Apollo 11]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="apollo-11"><![CDATA[Apollo 11]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Bob]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="bob"><![CDATA[Bob]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[McCalls]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mccalls"><![CDATA[McCalls]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[New York]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="new-york"><![CDATA[New York]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[New York City]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="new-york-city"><![CDATA[New York City]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Postage stamp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="postage-stamp"><![CDATA[Postage stamp]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Robert McCall]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="robert-mccall"><![CDATA[Robert McCall]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle-challenger-disaster"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Stained glass]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="stained-glass"><![CDATA[Stained glass]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=2212</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>(Ed. Note: I just heard the news that we lost the great Robert McCall. My heart goes out to his widow Louise and the rest of his family. His vision of the future will live on forever. I wrote the following piece about the McCalls in August of 1999. I had gone to visit them as part of my coverage of the 30th anniversary of the first moon landing. It was one of the better assignments I can recall...)</em>

[caption id="attachment_2211" align="alignleft" width="540" caption="Robert McCall inside the Chapel he created in Arizona in 1999."]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/02/McCalls-Chapel-2a.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-2211 " title="McCalls Chapel 2a" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/02/McCalls-Chapel-2a.jpg" alt="Robert McCall inside the Chapel he created in Arizona in 1999." width="540" height="456" /></a>[/caption]

PARADISE VALLEY, Arizona -- Even if you haven't heard of Robert McCall, you are still probably familiar with<a href="http://www.mccallstudios.com/" target="_blank"> his work</a>.

You will find his wide-eyed (and just plain wide) views of space -- past, present and future -- spanning the entry hall of the Smithsonian's Air and Space Museum; at the Horizons pavilion at Disney's EPCOT center; in old movie posters for "2001: A Space Odyssey," or in a two-decade-long series of postage stamps depicting space themes (talk about pushing the envelope ...).

<!--more-->

No, Robert McCall may not be a household name, but his work has household familiarity. An art school graduate from Columbus, Ohio, with a lifelong fascination with things that fly, McCall has illustrated the reality and the dreams the space age since it all began more than 40 years ago.

I got the idea for doing a story on McCall during a visit to NASA Administrator Dan Goldin's office. I was thinking of ways of telling the Apollo 11 anniversary story when I stumbled onto my inspiration. Prominently displayed just outside Goldin's door is a McCall "Mars-scape" depicting astronauts at work on the red planet.

It is vintage McCall. The machinery is intriguing and detailed, the spacefarers seem as if they are part of a heraldic pageant (as a boy, he had a fascination with drawing knights in shining armor) and the terrain is rugged and sweeping.

Actually, those mountains are reminiscent of the range that lies outside McCall's picture window (naturally) in his roomy studio at his home here. He says he moved to Arizona (from New York) in 1970 after a visit left him artistically inspired and personally enamored with the lifestyle.

Pass through the antique Mexican doors into the courtyard of McCall's home, and you will be greeted by the other artist in this residence: Bob's wife of more than 50 years, Louise.

While Bob's head was up in the clouds (literally and figuratively) for most of his artistic career, Louise has remained well grounded (literally and figuratively). She is a painter of flowers -- and a fine and prolific one at that. For years her career was overshadowed by Bob's success and sidetracked by the demands of raising two daughters.
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="left">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="220">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td colspan="2"><!--===========IMAGE============--> <!--===========/IMAGE===========--></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td width="12"></td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
She served as an adviser and assistant to Bob as his career took flight. But it's obvious what collaboration they are most proud of. We followed them down the road a few miles to see it -- at their church (Valley Presbyterian).

When the congregation decided to add a small, chapel-in-the-round for smaller ceremonies a few years ago, they called upon this artistic pair in their midst to design the stained-glass windows. Standing in the middle of the chapel, the pair guided me through the work.

With a rising sun, a constellation of stars and planets and heavenly symbolism wrapping around above, and of course, some of Louise's flowers rooted in the panes that rise from the floor, the McCalls' beautiful glass tells a story of faith and hope and optimism.

Not long after it was finished, and not long after the Challenger disaster, the widow of the commander of the doomed flight, June Scobee visited here. After gazing into the glass and reflecting, she told the McCall's she <em>knew</em> where her husband was. The McCalls' eyes glisten as they recount the story.

We spent two marvelous days with the McCalls -- seeing them at work -- talking with them about life in general. They seemed like a young couple. It is hard to believe they are well into their 70s.

That's what happens when you have -- and share -- a passion. You never really grow old.
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=400c5532-62bb-4117-ae4f-f01c4392a475" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Vietnam war]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="vietnam-war"><![CDATA[Vietnam war]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=2186</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[youtubevid id="-5UFIQGCzGc"]

Mr. Bolden goes to Capitol Hill this week...

The NASA boss <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/about/highlights/bolden_bio.html" target="_blank">Charlie Bolden</a> is a former Marine fighter and test pilot and astronaut and he is used to taking flak - after all he flew a hundred combat missions over southeast Asia during the Vietnam war. So facing off with some lawmakers on Capitol Hill over the controversial Obama NASA budget proposal - piece of cake- right?  Well, it started out that way - he began with the<a href="http://commerce.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?p=ScienceandSpace" target="_blank"> Senate Subcommittee on Science &amp; Space</a>.  The chairman - his former shuttle crew member - then Congressman - now <a href="http://billnelson.senate.gov/" target="_blank">Senator Bill Nelson</a>.  Watch their exchange <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-5UFIQGCzGc&amp;start=48" target="_blank">here.</a>

And a somewhat chillier one with <a href="http://vitter.senate.gov/public/" target="_blank">Senator David Vitter</a> - a Republican from Louisiana - home of the Michoud Assembly facility - where they make the external fuel tanks for the shuttle- <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-5UFIQGCzGc&amp;start=158" target="_blank">here.</a>

And I got in on the action too...<a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-5UFIQGCzGc&amp;start=1342" target="_blank">Here </a>is some of what I had to say. And you can read my full remarks<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/2010/02/24/to-the-moon-i-think-not-alice/" target="_blank"> here</a>.

The next day - Charlie Bolden found himself in a different orbit - namely the House of Representatives - where they don't know comity - from comedy...and when he appeared before the <a href="http://science.house.gov/subcommittee/space.aspx" target="_blank">House Science Committee</a>, it was so silly you almost had to laugh as members from Texas Alabama and Florida tried to out Bolden-bash one another.

[caption id="attachment_2188" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Cygnus Spacecraft.  Source:  Orbital Sciences"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/02/orbital.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2188" title="orbital" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/02/orbital-300x197.jpg" alt="Cygnus Spacecraft.  Source:  Orbital Sciences" width="300" height="197" /></a>[/caption]

The Obama budget for the space agency puts some big bets on some commercial players to work more independently to get cargo - and ultimately humans to and from low earth orbit. But there are a host of concerns about transferring so much risk outside the space agency. One of the main players in this game is <a href="http://www.orbital.com/" target="_blank">Orbital Sciences</a> - Like its competitor <a href="http://www.spacex.com/" target="_blank">SpaceX</a>, the company is building a vehicle to deliver cargo to the ISS under contract to NASA. Veteran astronaut and NASA manager <a href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/culberts.html" target="_blank">Frank Culbertson</a> is now a senior VP with orbital - and he was listening intently - as I was  - when his former fellow astronaut <a href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/gibson.html">Hoot Gibson</a> said this in that Senate Hearing.  Watch and listen to our conversation <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-5UFIQGCzGc&amp;start=820" target="_blank">here</a>.
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=6f0262a5-36cb-4ed5-8184-a757b64e6710" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"> </span></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Sadly, most of the words from elected officials are posturing for future elections, as they defend local jobs. Can we blame them for following the script we have written for them? I sure wish they would speak more about the capabilities that we are willingly abandoning, the missions we will not consider since we lost the ability to do them.
Our "new" capabilities, when they arrive, will not include doing EVA from a capsule. They will not include an RMS capability.
In the end, as long as our elected officials can claim that they will get more money in "the new budget" they will move on to other concerns. Later, if they money never shows up they will feign surprise and shock.
I am reminded of a scene in my favorite movie where Rick's Cafe Americain is shut down when the Chief of Police discovers gambling taking place! He is shocked and dismayed!]]></wp:comment_content>

		<item>
		<title>Shuttles and Astronauts</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/02/28/shuttles-and-astronauts/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 28 Feb 2010 23:04:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Discovery]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="discovery"><![CDATA[Discovery]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="endeavour"><![CDATA[Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="international-space-station"><![CDATA[International Space Station]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="kennedy-space-center"><![CDATA[Kennedy Space Center]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Soichi Noguchi]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="soichi-noguchi"><![CDATA[Soichi Noguchi]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Endeavour]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="space-shuttle-endeavour"><![CDATA[Space Shuttle Endeavour]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=2190</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_2191" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Endeavour lands at the Kennedy Space Center.  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/sts-130-lands.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2191" title="STS-130 lands" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/sts-130-lands.jpg?w=300" alt="Endeavour lands at the Kennedy Space Center.  Source:  NASA" width="300" height="199" /></a>[/caption]

The Space Shuttle <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/shuttle"></a><a href="www.nasa.gov/shuttle" target="_blank">Endeavour</a> was fresh off its night time landing at the Kennedy Space Center. The 6 person crew - led by Marine Colonel <a href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/zamka.html" target="_blank">George Zamka</a> - the guy they call Zambo - logged a successful mission to the Space Station - installing the Tranquility Node - with its stunning Cupola. Matter of fact station keeper <a href="http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/noguchi.html" target="_blank">Soichi Noguchi</a> watched Endeavour streak through re-entry  "He <a href="http://twitter.com/astro_Soichi" target="_blank">tweeted </a>that "The view was definitely out-of-the-world."
<blockquote>Not a haiku - no

But he uses left side brain

I cut him some slack</blockquote>
I'm a poet - bet ya didn't know it...

[caption id="attachment_2193" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Discovery in the Vehicle Assembly Building.  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/discovery-vertical.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2193" title="discovery vertical" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/discovery-vertical.jpg?w=300" alt="Discovery in the Vehicle Assembly Building.  Source:  NASA" width="300" height="225" /></a>[/caption]

From Haikus to minuets - TWIS is taking you upscale this week - with the precisely choreographed moved from horizontal to vertical - no I am not talking about getting out of bed with a hangover -

I am speaking of <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/shuttle" target="_blank">Discovery's</a> move from the orbital processing facility - or hangar - to the vertical assembly building for mating. Don't worry teachers - shuttle mating is G rated. It's all about connecting the orbiter to its big burnt orange external fuel tank - which has the solid rocket boosters attached to it. The finished product - the space shuttle stack - is slated to begin its slow roll to the launch pad on March 2nd. Launch to the space station is set for April 5th. Don't forget the best place to watch the launch is on<a href="http://www.spaceflightnow.com" target="_blank"> Spaceflight Now</a>.

When the shuttle stops flying - the US government will no longer be in the business of building spacecraft for its astronauts to fly into space. We can only hope this is a temporary suspension in membership of a very elite club. Still the Obama space budget says the <a href="http://sites.nationalacademies.org/NRC/index.htm" target="_blank">National Research Council</a> will take a hard look at role and size of the astronaut corps. No Bucks - no need for Buck Rogers. But in India - they are ready to invest some rupees on future Ramu Ramjets. The nation's <a href="http://www.isro.org/" target="_blank">space agency</a> says it is ready to join the club -  they are vowing to send a pair of astronauts into space in the next six or seven years...not wise to curry...

<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/atk-logo-bg.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2194" title="atk-logo-bg" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/atk-logo-bg.jpg" alt="atk-logo-bg" width="200" height="160" /></a>And from our very busy "last-ever " desk - an item this week from Big Love Country - northern Utah...Rocket builder <a href="http://www.atk.com/" target="_blank">ATK</a> staged its last test firing of a shuttle solid rocket motor. Since 1988, ATK has conducted 34 ground tests during to verify performance and safety margins - and test new materials. ATK says it will march ahead with a static test of an Ares 1 style booster - even though that program is a goner - NASA has already paid for it - and the show will go on.

Watch these stories from "This Week in Space" Version 8 below:

[youtubevid id="-5UFIQGCzGc"]

		<item>
		<title>Geysers, Oceans and Dinosaurs</title>
		<link>http://milesobrien.wordpress.com/2010/02/28/geysers-oceans-and-dinosaurs/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 28 Feb 2010 23:13:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[milesobrien]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Cassini]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="cassini"><![CDATA[Cassini]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Cassini–Huygens]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="cassini%e2%80%93huygens"><![CDATA[Cassini–Huygens]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Enceladus]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="enceladus"><![CDATA[Enceladus]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[European Space Agency]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="european-space-agency"><![CDATA[European Space Agency]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[European Space Agency]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="european-space-agency"><![CDATA[European Space Agency]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Hubble]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="hubble"><![CDATA[Hubble]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Hubble Space Telescope]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="hubble-space-telescope"><![CDATA[Hubble Space Telescope]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Italian Space Agency]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="italian-space-agency"><![CDATA[Italian Space Agency]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="nasa"><![CDATA[NASA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Saturn]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="saturn"><![CDATA[Saturn]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="science"><![CDATA[Science]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="space"><![CDATA[Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Spacecraft]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="spacecraft"><![CDATA[Spacecraft]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="this-week-in-space"><![CDATA[This Week In Space]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Water]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="water"><![CDATA[Water]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=2199</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_2200" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Jets on Enceladus.  Source:  Cassini"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/enceladus1.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2200" title="Enceladus1" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/enceladus1.jpg?w=300" alt="Jets on Enceladus.  Source:  Cassini" width="300" height="185" /></a>[/caption]

Saturn's moon Enceladus is spewing out some impressive geysers of water ice.  The NASA/ESA Italian space agency team that flies the Cassini spacecraft just released this <a href="http://ciclops.org/view/6023/Bursting_at_the_Seams" target="_blank">composite image</a> captured in November showing about 30 of the jets near the south pole of that moon. The big question for those who are interested in life beyond our planet - could their be liquid water reservoirs beneath the surface?  As you know - wherever water is found in liquid form on this planet - you will find living things.  So...Let me be the first to tell any prospective Enceladians - we come in peace.

[caption id="attachment_2202" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="SMOS Image.  Source:  ESA"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/smos1.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2202" title="SMOS1" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/smos1.jpg?w=300" alt="SMOS Image.  Source:  ESA" width="300" height="193" /></a>[/caption]

Another ESA satellite is focused on water as well - just a little closer to home...These are the first calibration images from the the <a href="http://www.esa.int/esaCP/SEMOGN3KV5G_index_0.html">Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity</a> - or (SMOS) mission.  - Launched in November this satellite is designed to help scientists better understand the water cycle on earth - and that will help them improve weather and climate models.

[caption id="attachment_2204" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Jurassic Space.  Source:  Hubble Space Telescope"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/jurassic-space-small.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2204" title="Jurassic Space small" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/jurassic-space-small.jpg?w=300" alt="Jurassic Space.  Source:  Hubble Space Telescope" width="300" height="279" /></a>[/caption]

Kids love space and dinosaurs - so I have always believed if we could just put a dinosaur into space - we would have a nation of space loving high achievers in math and science...well voila...astronomers using the<a href="http://hubblesite.org/newscenter/archive/releases/2010/08/" target="_blank"> Hubble Space Telescope </a>have found some galaxies that are tantamount to seeing a dinosaur wander into your backyard. It's a group of small galaxies that are still in the early stages of formation - but they are much closer to us - only 166 million light years - and thus much younger than galaxies at a similar stage that scientists have seen before. For some reason these small galaxies waited 10 billion years to get together.  Now that's a long courtship...see this story in video form <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-5UFIQGCzGcstart=1230" target="_blank">here</a>.

Watch Enceladus and SMOS stories on "This Week in Space" version 8 here:

[youtubevid id="-5UFIQGCzGc"]
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=85776401-acc0-49cf-bc90-8c32199d97a5" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"> </span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=2254</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The latest edition of "This Week In Space" - hosted by Yours Truly, is out!  Watch here!

[youtubevid id="S5icnMDAGsI"]

[caption id="attachment_2255" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Map of the North Pole of the Moon.  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/moon-ice.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2255" title="moon ice" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/moon-ice-150x150.jpg" alt="Map of the North Pole of the Moon.  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

I gotta admit,  I am getting a little tired of launching the program with the latest skirmish in the war over the Obama NASA space budget - it's not that I don't care - but frankly I am more interested in learning something new about the Cosmos - not Congress. How about you? So this week, I am starting in the orbit of the moon - where a high tech divining rod built by the U.S. - hitching a ride on an Indian spacecraft Chandrayaan-1 - has found there is a whole lot of <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/Mini-RF/multimedia/feature_ice_like_deposits.html" target="_blank">water ice</a> down there. And here is the proof...NASA's Mini-SAR radar is the instrument - and it found the ice in more than 40 small craters where the sun don't shine. So how much ice is there? 1.3 trillion pounds (600 million metric tons).  Another reason to visit the moon - it will be easy to keep the beer cold.

[caption id="attachment_2256" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Buzz Aldrin"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/Buzz-Aldrin.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2256" title="Buzz Aldrin" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/Buzz-Aldrin-150x114.jpg" alt="Buzz Aldrin" width="150" height="114" /></a>[/caption]

Tempting as a toga party in 1/6th gravity might be - we are not heading back to the moon anytime soon - and the second man to leave footprints up there is just fine with that. Buzz Aldrin is pushing a plan called the <a href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/07/15/AR2009071502940.html" target="_blank">Unified Space Vision</a> - which earmarks money to build a heavy lift booster - and a craft that would only operate in space called the Exploration Module - or XM (he's Sirius about XM).  The XM's would be built from parts left over from space station construction - carried to orbit by shuttles - oh yeah - he wants to fly several more shuttle missions. I Skyped Buzz to hear more.   A lot of others are looking to get more funding for NASA - Kay Bailey Hutchison - the Senator from Shuttleland has ginned up a bill that would add 1.3 billion dollars more to the Obama NASA budget.  The money would be used to fly the shuttle fleet indefinitely.  All of this is grist for the so called "Plan B" team that is working on a compromise plan inside NASA that might bridge the gap between the White House and the Hill. Enough said - stay tuned.

[caption id="attachment_2257" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Discovery at pad 39A.  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/discovery.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2257" title="discovery" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/discovery-150x150.jpg" alt="Discovery at launchpad 39A.  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

Meanwhile the serious business of launching a <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/shuttle" target="_blank">shuttle</a> safely moves on in earnest - and in slow motion at the Cape.  TWIS Correspondent David Waters was there the other day as Discovery and her entourage - made her way to the pad - like a herd of turtles.

Liftoff is currently targeted for April 5.  Please join David, me, and astronaut Leroy Chiao at <a href="http://www.spaceflightnow.com" target="_blank">Spaceflight Now</a> for comprehensive coverage of the launch.

[caption id="attachment_1188" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="International Space Station.  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/12/ISS.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1188" title="ISS" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2009/12/ISS-150x150.jpg" alt="International Space Station.  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

<!--more-->It's the aerospace equivalent of the Stanley Cup, the Hiesman Trophy or the green blazer at Augusta - it has just been bestowed on the <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/station">International Space Station</a> team. The National Aeronautic Association in Washington awarding the prestigious Collier trophy to the orbiting outpost. The trophy is named for Robert J. Collier, - of Collier's magazine fame - which in 1952 and 53 published a seminal illustrated series that popularized the exploration of space - Collier created the trophy in 1910 to recognize the greatest achievements in aviation and aeronautics. ISS joins Glenn Curtis, Orville Wright, both Rutan brohers and Chuck Yeager in the Collier club. Rarefied air indeed. Nice work Station Nation!<a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S5icnMDAGsI&amp;start=769" target="_blank"> </a>

[caption id="attachment_2259" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Early artist&#039;s rendering for X-37B."]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/X-37B.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2259" title="X-37B" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/X-37B-150x150.jpg" alt="Early artist's rendering for X-37B." width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

A secret military spacecraft is marching toward a mid April launch at Cape Caneveral...The <a href="http://www.spaceflightnow.com/atlas/av012/100225x37arrival/" target="_blank">x-37B</a>, which looks like a model rocket builders attempt to knock off the shuttle, will be doing - well - secret stuff - for the Air Force. The unmanned reusable will ride to orbit on the shoulders of an Atlas 5 rocket. After it is done doing whatever it will be doing, it will return for a landing at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California. But we are not sure when...it's a secret.

[caption id="attachment_1436" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Courtesy:  SpaceX"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/01/Falcon9-on-Pad1.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1436" title="Falcon9 on Pad" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/01/Falcon9-on-Pad1-150x150.jpg" alt="Courtesy:  SpaceX" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

Also from our Cape Canaveral launch desk - word that the not-so-secret Falcon 9 program had a good day the other day...they staged a so called Wet Dress Rehearsal - which doesn't mean they sang show tunes in the rain.  No it means they fueled up their rocket - did a countdown - and had the smoothest test to date - according the their launch director. <a href="http://www.spacex.com">SpaceX </a>founder Elon Musk declared it a "good day" - the next milestone - a so called hot fire test - which means they will count down and light the engines for three and a half seconds. The inaugural launch is set for no earlier than March 22nd.

[caption id="attachment_2260" align="alignright" width="150" caption="GOES P Launch.  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/GoesP.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2260" title="GoesP" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/GoesP-150x150.jpg" alt="GOES P Launch.  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

There she GOES! NASA launched the 15th Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite - or "GOES - P" the other day. The satellite got a ride to space on a Delta 4 rocket. The National Weather Service uses the <a href="http://goes.gsfc.nasa.gov/" target="_blank">GOES</a> system to monitor and forecast the weather and researchers use them to better understand climate change. So weather all goes well - is important...

[caption id="attachment_2062" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Mars Express.  Source:  ESA"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/02/MarsExpress01_L.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2062" title="MarsExpress01_L" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/02/MarsExpress01_L-150x150.jpg" alt="Mars Express.  Source:  ESA" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

ESA's Mars Express spcecraft buzzed the Martian moon <a href="http://www.esa.int/esaCP/SEMIPX6K56G_index_0.html" target="_blank">Phobos</a> the other night at an altitude of only 67 kilometers - or 41 miles - and look at what it saw.  Scientists believe Phobos is little more than a a pile of rubble glommed together - with some substantial voids - maybe as much as 25 or 25 per cent porous. They are trying to get precise measurements of Phobus' gravity field. It is likely Phobos formed after Mars - and will eventually be pulled apart as the planet pulls it closer. Rubble to rubble I guess.

[caption id="attachment_2261" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Stardust.  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/stardust.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-2261" title="stardust" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/stardust.jpg" alt="Stardust.  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="120" /></a>[/caption]

The <a href="http://stardustnext.jpl.nasa.gov/" target="_blank">Stardust</a> spacecraft - which made history by sending some comet bits back to earth 4 years ago - is looking for some more work...and so it will swing by the Comet Temple 1 - on Valentine''s Day next year. You will forgive Temple 1 if it ducks when it sees Stardust coming - as the last spacecraft we sent its way in 2005 -  Deep Impact - augured right in to the comet - to see what it is made of. Stardust will just fly by however - to see how Tempel 1 has recovered.

[caption id="attachment_2264" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="&quot;Blue Marble&quot; Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/bluemarble.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2264" title="bluemarble" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/bluemarble-150x150.jpg" alt="&quot;Blue Marble&quot; Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

We sure do live on a pretty planet don't we? You can savor that fact by clicking your way to the <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/gsfc/" target="_blank">Flickr Feed</a> for NASA's Goddard Spaceflight Center. There you will find a series of the most detailed hi rez images of our little globe ever captured. Most of the images stitched together to make this stunning view were captured by NASA’s Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer, or MODIS - which is bolted onto the Terra satellite in low earth orbit. We may be a knockout of a of a planet - but we have issues - check out <a href="http://www.esa.int/esaEO/SEMUD27K56G_index_0.html" target="_blank">these images</a> from the european space agency's envisat satelltie - it shows a 97 kilometer - 60 mile long - iceberg hitting the Mertz glacier tongue in Antarctica on February 10th. This made a new iceberg. The pair have drifted into an area where dense cold bottom water is normally formed...the bergs could upset that process. In case you hadn't noticed - the days on earth got a little shorter since our last program - by 1.26 microseconds.  The magnitude 8.8 quake in Chile shifted enough mass to slightly change the rate at which the world turns - a milisecond is a millionth of a second...so no wonder I am not getting anything done.

[caption id="attachment_2265" align="alignright" width="150" caption="The B1608+656 system.  Source:  Sherry Suyu of the Argelander Institut für Astronomie in Bonn, Germany"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/age-of-universe.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2265" title="age of universe" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/age-of-universe-150x150.jpg" alt="The B1608+656 system.  Source:  Sherry Suyu of the Argelander Institut für Astronomie in Bonn, Germany" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

As long as we are marking time here - a global team of researchers has narrowed down the age of the universe to 13.75 billion years - give or take a 170 million. The team led by Stanford's <a href="http://home.slac.stanford.edu/pressreleases/2010/20100301.htm" target="_blank">Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology </a>used a technique called gravitational lensing to get a better handle on how far away distant galaxies are. They measure the light from the distant object as it passes through a closer galaxy - taking more than one path. Measuring the different arrival times of the light is the secret sauce to making more precise measurements of distance - and  time.

[caption id="attachment_2193" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Discovery in the Vehicle Assembly Building.  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/02/discovery-vertical.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2193" title="discovery vertical" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/02/discovery-vertical-150x150.jpg" alt="Discovery in the Vehicle Assembly Building.  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

Time is running out for the space shuttle program – which means people who work on it will soon be laid off.  …and more could be laid off if Constellation is indeed canceled.  Now a new study shows startling new layoff estimates for the area nicknamed the space Coast.  And David Waters says the study shows the majority of layoffs will be for people who don’t work in the space industry.

[caption id="attachment_2267" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Richard Covey.  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/covey.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2267" title="covey" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/covey-150x150.jpg" alt="Richard Covey.  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

And more proof of things are winding down for the shuttle program - Dick Covey, the man who runs the prime shuttle contractor,<a href="http://www.unitedspacealliance.com/" target="_blank"> United Space Alliance</a> - is calling it a day - retiring effective March 26th. Covey flew on four shuttle missions - was commander of the return to flight after Challenger - and the first Hubble repair mission. He has been CEO at USA since 2006.  A successor is "in work" as they say...

Superstition holds that death comes in threes - well sadly that turned out to be true since our last episode. Three great members of the space community are now among the stars...

[caption id="attachment_2268" align="alignleft" width="144" caption="Aaron Cohen  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/Aaron-Cohen.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2268" title="Aaron Cohen" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/Aaron-Cohen-144x150.jpg" alt="Aaron Cohen  Source:  NASA" width="144" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

Aaron Cohen - the legendary former director of the Johnson Space Center died at the age of 79. He joined NASA in 1963 - and worked also as chief systems engineer for the Apollo Command and Service Module and the Lunar Module, then manager of the Space Shuttle program. He ran JSC in the aftermath of the Challenger disaster. NASA administrator Charlie Bolden was in the astronaut office at the time - and said this week - Cohen "provided the critical and calm guidance needed...to successfully recover from the Challenger accident... "

[caption id="attachment_2269" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Bill Taub  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/Bill-Taub.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2269" title="Bill Taub" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/Bill-Taub-150x150.jpg" alt="Bill Taub  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

And the man responsible for some of the iconic images of the moon race has moved onto another orbit as well. <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/topics/people/features/taub_gallery.html" target="_blank">Bill Taub</a> was NASA's first senior photographer - and covered every event from Mercury through Apollo. Here he is getting a <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/images/content/431109main_69-H-1112_full.jpg" target="_blank">blood test</a> so that he could be cleared to be near the quarantined Apollo 11 crew before launch. Taub told an interviewer once "I had the privilege to be there to record it. I made sure I recorded it to the best of my ability, because I have a sense of history." We can all be glad he had the front row seat to history.

[caption id="attachment_2272" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Robert McCall  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/Robert-McCall.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2272" title="Robert McCall" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/Robert-McCall-150x150.jpg" alt="Robert McCall  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

And the brilliant space artist<a href="http://www.nasa.gov/topics/people/features/mccall_gallery.html" target="_blank"> Robert McCall</a> has left us as well. McCall painted stunning grand visions of space exploration - which you probably have seen - including a huge mural in the National Air and Space Museum. Isaac Asimov called him “the nearest thing we have to an artist in residence in outer space.” McCall was 90. He was the artist that everyone figured would fly on the shuttle when the civilians in space program got started in the mid eighties. Of course Challenger ended that dream for him. I had the good fortune to spend some time with him and his wife Lousie at their home in Arizona ten years ago - they were just fabulous - and fun and young at heart. That's what happens when you pursue your passion with gusto. Robert McCall may be gone - but his vision for the future will live on forever.

[caption id="attachment_2273" align="alignright" width="150" caption="NGC 1068  Source:   Chandra X-Ray Observatory"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/chandra.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2273" title="chandra" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/chandra-150x150.jpg" alt="NGC 1068  Source:   Chandra X-Ray Observatory" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

Here is an idea and an image that would get Bob McCall's creative juices - and oil paint flowing...there is new evidence black holes don't just suck things in - they blow powerful winds out. NASA's <a href="http://chandra.harvard.edu/photo/2010/ngc1068/" target="_blank">Chandra X-Ray Observatory </a>made the finding when scientists pointed its High Energy Transmission Grating Spectrometer at the galaxy known as NGC 1068. Turns out the supermassive blackhole in that neck of the woods sends out wind at a rate of a million miles an hour - making it a category 50 thousand storm...must be climate change...

[caption id="attachment_2274" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Source:  European Southern Observatory"]<a href="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/cosmic-bat.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2274" title="cosmic bat" src="http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/files/2010/03/cosmic-bat-150x150.jpg" alt="Source:  European Southern Observatory" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

Now let's move over to the Orion constellation - and I am not talking about canceled rockets and spacecraft - I am talking about a place in the cosmos  where they aren't worried about NASA's budget. The <a href="http://www.eso.org/public/news/eso1009/" target="_blank">European Southern Observatory </a>aimed at Orion - and got this stunning shot of a little nebula - the gas glows from the light of the young stars that are inside.

Actress Jennifer Aniston - now there's a name you might not have expected to hear  <em>here</em> - is apparently enamored with the stars - and we are not talking about the red carpet variety.  The site celebrity gossip.net (what? you don't have an RSS feed from them?) says Aniston just popped for a three thousand dollar Celestron. A source tells the site Jennifer is alway looking for ways to expand her horizons. Or maybe in pointing big lens at a star - she is trying to understand what its like to be a paparazzo.

Well he may be 80 and have two left feet - but you could never accuse the second man who walked on the moon of shying away from a challenge  - or the limelight. Buzz Aldrin will be on Dancing with the Stars  this season - he is pared with a 27 year old professional dancer named Ashly Costa. This season premiers on March 22nd. - and I ask Buzz about the Moonwalk.
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=a186cce9-74ec-47ca-a977-ad2e4fcedc83" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The latest edition of "This Week in Space" is now available.  Check us out!

[youtubevid id="hqycNoARYv4"]

<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble8.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/03/Hubble2.jpg"><img class="alignright size-thumbnail wp-image-2305" title="Hubble2" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble8.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/03/Hubble2-150x150.jpg" alt="Hubble2" width="150" height="150" /></a>Hello and welcome - President Obama will finally say something about his plan for NASA - but there are still mixed messages coming out of the space agency - as the space shuttle program winds down - and new commercial players try to spin up. And while SpaceX tried to figure out why a launch pad test ended before it really got started - We are told by the man in charge of the shuttle program that the fleet doesn't have to stop flying after 4 more flights - it is just a matter of money...more on all of this in a bit - but first I have to tell you about tje Warner Brothers <a href="http://www.imax.com/hubble/" target="_blank">"IMAX: Hubble 3D"</a> movie that captures some of the space shuttle's greatest moments - and gives those of us who have never been to space - an idea of what it is really like to be there. I am talking about the IMAX Hubble 3-D movie - which premiered this week at the Air and Space Museum in Washington...The movie focuses on the last Hubble repair mission in May. NASA  bolted a 3-D IMAX camera into the payload bay of Atlantis - it captured the astronauts at work in a vivid big screen - in your face - kinda way.

<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2306" title="Hubble1" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble1.jpg?w=150" alt="Hubble1" width="150" height="150" /></a>Leonardo DiCaprio narrates the film. Hubble 3D also includes scenes from the first Hubble repair mission - and the deployment of the telescope as well. But this time there is something different - IMAX took some of the most iconic images captured by Hubble - to the <a href="http://www.ncsa.illinois.edu/" target="_blank">National Center for Super Computing Applications at the University of Illinois Ubrana-Champaign</a> - there the filmmakers and the computer whizzes made those images 3-D - so in this movie not only do you feel as if you are flying on board the shuttle - you also are treated to an amazing 3-D odyssey through distant galaxies and nebulas. It's an amazing ride...

<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble3.jpg"><img class="alignright size-thumbnail wp-image-2307" title="Hubble3" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble3.jpg?w=150" alt="Hubble3" width="150" height="150" /></a>They rolled out the red carpet at the Air and Space museum for the premiere - the space glitterati - such as it is - was there in large numbers - to see the Hubble 3-D. Now Leonardo sent his regrets from a movie set in Japan - and the real star of the show - Hubble was unable to be there was well - so that meant the big stars of the evening were the crew members of <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts125/main/index.html" target="_blank">STS-125</a> - decked out in their blue flight suits - ready for their closeups. The crew of course felt a ton of pressure to fix and improve Hubble for the last time - so you would think shooting the movie would be no problem at all. But get this - they only had 8 minutes worth of film in that 3-D camera in the payload bay. And the camera only shoots 30 seconds at a time. So they had to be extremely careful about when to say "action" - but they had trained for it long and hard - and it all paid off. I spoke to these John Glenn Steven Spielberg hybrids as they walked down the carpet.

<!--more--><a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble8.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/03/Hubble5.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2310" title="Hubble5" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble8.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/03/Hubble5-150x150.jpg" alt="Hubble5" width="150" height="150" /></a>Of course IMAX has a long history of making big screen space films - matter of fact this is the seventh big picture from their space team. They are led by producer director <a href="http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0616880/" target="_blank">Toni Myers</a> - I spoke with her about the challenges of making a movie where the director cannot actually be on location - and yet has has to get the most important shots recorded on one 8 minute film magazine.

<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble6.jpg"><img class="alignright size-thumbnail wp-image-2311" title="hubble6" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble6.jpg?w=150" alt="hubble6" width="150" height="150" /></a>The IMAX 3-D experience is designed to take you to another place like no other medium can. It is the perfect way to share the experience of space flight. And give NASA credit for making all of this happen - the cameras take up a lot of space, weight and crew training time. And let's remember - back in the Apollo days - NASA engineers argued against taking TV cameras to the moon - because there was no mission requirement to do so - and the cameras would add too much weight. Well we've come a long way baby - I asked NASA's deputy administrator <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/about/highlights/garver_bio.html" target="_blank">Lori Garver </a>- who once tried to go to space herself - what she thinks about this way of engaging the public.

[caption id="attachment_1435" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Source:  SpaceX"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble8.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/01/Falcon9-on-Pad.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1435" title="Falcon9 on Pad" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble8.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/01/Falcon9-on-Pad-150x150.jpg" alt="Source:  SpaceX" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

It was quite a  scene at the Falcon 9 "hotfire" test the other day in Florida...there was a hot fire - briefly - but after that nothing.  Launch controllers aborted the test of the engines at T-2 seconds. Falcon nine's nine "Merlin 1-C" engines were supposed to fire for 3 and a half seconds to verify that all systems are functioning" and ready to roll for lift-off.   the fire and smoke you see is the burn off of some residual liquid oxygen and kerosene fuel - the company says the engines never actually fired.  They'll be trying again in the coming days - this is the last big milestone before their maiden test voyage.  All eyes are on SpaceX, as it races competitor Orbital Sciences to be the first commercial company to start hauling cargo, and one day people, back and forth to the International Space Station under contract with NASA.

<!--more-->

[caption id="attachment_2257" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Discovery at launchpad 39A.  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble8.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/03/discovery.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2257" title="discovery" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble8.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/03/discovery-150x150.jpg" alt="Discovery at launchpad 39A.  Source:  NASA" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

Of course, not everyone is ready to go "all-in" on the plan to turn access to space over to the private sector. In the House Florida lawmakers <a href="http://www.kosmas.house.gov/" target="_blank">Suzanne Kosmas </a>and <a href="http://posey.house.gov/" target="_blank">Bill Posey </a>introduced a bill that would earmark money to fly the shuttle's past the current retirement - <a href="http://hutchison.senate.gov/" target="_blank">Kay Bailey Hutchison </a>has introduced a similar bill on the senate side.  And Now Shuttle Program Manager says there is no reason the shuttle can't keep on flying... John Shannon telling reporters it is a myth that NASA would have  trouble getting shuttle vendors to restart production. But what about recertification of the orbiters - a requirement that came out of the Columbia accident...he says the agency has done enough of that to fly safely.  The "tall pole in the tent," as they say at NASA, would be external tank production.  Even if the folks at Lockheed Martin got the word today to start making tanks again, there would still be a two year gap in any future shuttle flights  But the bottom says Shannon - is the bottom line.

[caption id="attachment_2145" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Orion orbiting the Moon"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble8.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/02/nasa-cev-orion.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2145" title="nasa-cev-orion" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble8.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/02/nasa-cev-orion-150x150.jpg" alt="Orion orbiting the Moon" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

That money is NOT in the Obama Administration's 2011 NASA Budget, nor are dollars for the<a href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/constellation/main/" target="_blank"> Constellation Project</a> to return astronauts to the moon. It is a big change - and up to now we have not heard the president say a peep about it - but that is about to change.  The White House announcing Obama will be in Florida on April 15 to host a conference on the future of America's space program.  Details are all still TBA.  You can bet, however,  the President will offer a spirited defense of his plan to promote commercial transportation services to low earth orbit, and reorient NASA's efforts toward developing new technologies for exploration beyond LEO.  You can also bet he's gonna get an earful from a lot of angry folks on the Space Coast who are headed for the unemployment line.

<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble7.jpg"><img class="alignright size-thumbnail wp-image-2312" title="hubble7" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble7.jpg?w=150" alt="hubble7" width="150" height="150" /></a>IMAX and NASA have had a good marriage over the years - and it all began at the site of the premier - the Smithsonian's Air and Space Museum - when it opened in in 1976 - IMAX was a brand new idea - the first movie to play there was "To Fly" -  the museum director at the time was Apollo 11 command module pilot Mike Collins - who immediately thought IMAX needed to go to space. The first product of that idea was "Hail Columbia" in 1982 - and the IMAX space hits have kept on coming...TWIS correspondent David Waters takes a look back.

<!--more--><a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble8.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2313" title="hubble8" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/hubble8.jpg?w=150" alt="hubble8" width="150" height="150" /></a>The Hubble space telescope is an amazing instrument - in order to focus on a distant target the school bus sized scope does not deviate more than 7 one thousandth of an arc second - that  is the same it try to hold a laser pointer steady on a dime that is 400 miles away. Hubble beams down about 120 gigabytes of data each week. the telescope is named for astronomer Edwin Hubble who confirmed the expansion of the universe - which led to the big bang theory. The ideas for a space telescope was conceived by the late Princeton astronomer Lyman Spitzer (another NASA telescope is named after him). If Hubble is the ancestor - and Spitzer the father - Ed Weiler might be called Hubble's uncle - the NASA astronomer and manager has been with the Hubble program since the blurry eyed beginning.

The IMAX Hubble 3-D movie opens worldwide at IMAX theatres on March 19.
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=65af52f2-6419-47a9-b0af-f6cca98b1614" alt="" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

Sincerely,

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="wide-field-infrared-survey-explorer"><![CDATA[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[WISE]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="wise"><![CDATA[WISE]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/?p=2327</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The latest edition of "This Week in Space" is now available!  Check us out!!  And many thanks to our sponsors, <a href="http://www.binary-space.com" target="_blank">Binary Space </a>and <a href="http://www.space-careers.com" target="_blank">Space Careers</a>!

[youtubevid id="yR7Gcio4r3g"]

[caption id="attachment_2257" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Discovery at launchpad 39A.  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/03/discovery.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2257" title="discovery" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/03/discovery-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

Two million parts - all of them form the low bidder - as Wally Schirra  once famously quipped - if you put those parts together just right - you've got yourself a <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/shuttle" target="_blank">space shuttle</a> - the problem is - just about every single one of them has to be working perfectly before a shuttle ever clears the tower.  But exceptions can be made....and that is what the shuttle launch team is doing for this next launch. With Discovery sitting on the launch pad for its penultimate flight - a helium valve  failed. The helium is used to make sure there is pressure in the fuel lines that feed the Orbital Maneuvering System engines - which handle the big course changes in orbit. Fixing the valve means a roll back to the the hangar - and a big delay. So the shuttle team will try to verify that some regulators downstream of the valve are working just fine. If so, it means they will have confidence they have only lost one layer of redundancy - and thus give Discovery its launching papers.

<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/wise-small.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2328" title="wise small" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/wise-small.jpg?w=150" alt="Source:  WISE" width="150" height="150" /></a>NASA's Wide Field Infrared Survey Explorer - or <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/WISE/main/index.html" target="_blank">WISE</a> has captured an image - Charles Foster Kane would have liked to see - rosebud....
this one is no sled though - it is a cosmic blossom in a cluster of stars in the Berkeley 59 - which sounds a little like a group of sixties anti war radicals...anyway...the blue dots are the stars...and they are formed by the orange dust cloud in the middle - and the green - those are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons - of course...you can find those on earth in barbecue pits...for some reason I am hungry...WISE is also hunting for asteroids - and it has found more than a dozen that are near to earth - and we didn't even know we were there. You'd be WISE to listen to this story - Chicken Littles.

<!--more--><a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/soho.jpg"><img class="alignright size-thumbnail wp-image-2331" title="soho" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/soho.jpg?w=150" alt="Source:  SOHO" width="150" height="150" /></a>Time now for our 90 second tour around the cosmos - brought to you by <a href="http://www.space-careers.com" target="_blank">Space Careers</a>.  Ever heard of a kamikaze comet? Check out this!  These <a href="http://sohowww.nascom.nasa.gov/pickoftheweek/" target="_blank">cool images</a> - come to us from the sun gazing SOHO spacecraft run by the European Space Agency and NASA. It shows a comet diving right into the sun. But apparently there was some sort of Heaven's Gate suicide pact going on with the comets - because some other smaller comets did the same thing...SOHO has never seen anything like this before.

Here's a good name for a planet in a B grade sci fi movie:  Corot 9B - it was found by the French satellite known as <a href="http://www.esa.int/esaSC/120372_index_0_m.html" target="_blank">Corot</a> along with The European Southern Observatory's HARPS exoplanet hunter...Corot 9B is 1500 hundred light years away from us toward the constellation Serpens (the snake). Astronomers say it is the first normal temperate exoplanet they can study in detail. Corot B is the size of Jupiter and is mostly made of hydrogen and helium. No sign of any Corotians...

<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/03/planck.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2332" title="planck" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/03/planck-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a>And the universe sure could use a cleaning service - would you look at this dust..<a href="http://www.esa.int/SPECIALS/Planck/SEMMN9CKP6G_0.html">.these giant filaments of cold dust</a> were captured by ESA's Max Planck satellite...the filaments are about 500 light years from the sun - virtually next door...the pink line near the bottom is the Milky Way. No one knows what makes the dust form these shapes.

And here is a new look at a familiar spot in our solar system - <a href="http://www.eso.org/public/news/eso1010/" target="_blank">new thermal images </a>of the Jupiter's Great Red Spot. which is a storm the size of three earths. The thermal image gives astronomers their first detailed look inside the storm. Scientists at NASA's Jet Propulsion Lab captured the image using the European Southern Observatory, the Gemini Observatory in Chile and Japan's Subaru telescope in Hawaii. They say the spot is a lot more complex than they once thought.

<!--more-->

[caption id="attachment_2062" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Mars Express.  Source:  ESA"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/02/MarsExpress01_L.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2062" title="MarsExpress01_L" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/02/MarsExpress01_L-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

More great, <a href="http://www.esa.int/esaCP/SEMK17CKP6G_index_0.html" target="_blank">new images</a> from the Martian moon of Phobos - they come from the European Space Agency's Mars Express spacecraft. The detail here is fantastic - about 4.4 meters - 14 and a half feet per pixel - like our moon - Phobos always shows the same face to the planet. Mars Express is also analyzing Phobos to see what it is made of. It bears a lot of similarity to carbonaceous asteroid - but some researchers believe it might be made up of rocky remnants from the days when Mars was being formed.

Meanwhile - a little farther out in our solar system  near Saturn - some other cool moons got a visit recently by a human made robot...this one is named <a href="http://saturn.jpl.nasa.gov/mission/flybys/rhea20100302/" target="_blank">Rhea</a> - and the ESA/NASA spacecraft <a href="http://saturn.jpl.nasa.gov/news/cassinifeatures/feature20100216/" target="_blank">Cassini</a> swooped down within 100 kilometers of the moon to get a sniff...Cassini's RADAR instrument performed scatterometry and radiometry measurement to try and determine what Rhea is made of. And then there is little <a href="http://saturn.jpl.nasa.gov/photos/imagedetails/index.cfm?imageId=3896">Helene</a> - no easy task to get a good flyby shot of something that small...and the Cassini team also released this cool image of <a href="http://saturn.jpl.nasa.gov/photos/imagedetails/index.cfm?imageId=3903" target="_blank">Saturn's rings</a> - partially obscured by the planet's shadow. Such a beautiful planet - my second favorite.

[caption id="attachment_1188" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="International Space Station.  Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpgmilesobrien/files/2009/12/ISS.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1188" title="ISS" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpgmilesobrien/files/2009/12/ISS-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

And a Russian Soyuz capsule carrying a pair of <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/station" target="_blank">International Space Station </a>keepers made its way to the surface of my favorite planet the other day. US Astronaut Jeff Williams and Russian cosmonaut Maxim Suraev arrived on the steppe of Kazakhstan. Strong winds toppled the capsule on its side. But the spacefarers were no worse for the wear - you know, any landing you can walk away from....the orbiting outpost they left behind may be in space as long as thirty years if all goes well technically and fiscally. The leaders of the station program met in Tokyo this past week to discuss extending the station's life to 2028. That would mark the thirtieth anniversary of the arrival in orbit of the cornerstone of the station - the FGB - which we now call Zarya. The Obama NASA budget earmarks money to keep the station aloft until 2020. But the engineers say there is no reason ISS cannot fly longer. Eventually it will need some new batteries.
<!--more-->The White House is hoping to charge up some enthusiasm for its plans for NASA. The President is headed into the lion's den on tax day. He will hold a summit on space at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida - where there are a lot of angry unemployed - or soon to be - space workers. Lots of talk the president may announce one more shuttle mission - and Florida Senator <a href="http://billnelson.senate.gov/" target="_blank">Bill Nelson</a> did not throw cold water on that idea after an Oval Office meeting with Obama - and vice president Joe Biden. Nelson expressed optimism after that chat - calling it an "excellent conversation."

[caption id="attachment_1436" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Courtesy:  SpaceX"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/01/Falcon9-on-Pad1.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1436" title="Falcon9 on Pad" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/01/Falcon9-on-Pad1-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

One of the big winners in the new "space" order - has apparently been having some excellent conversations with potential customers.<a href="http://www.spacex.com" target="_blank"> SpaceX</a> announcing it has inked a deal with satellite builder Loral to deliver one of its spacecraft to orbit as early as 2012. The announcement comes on the heels of that successful hotfire test of Spacex's Falcon 9 rocket. SpaceX is planning 2 dozen launches over the next five years. Loral says all those launches will mean it is assured a successful flight history in advance of its mission.

The Pentagon is complaining that it didn't get enough advance consultation from the White House before it released its plan to cancel the back-to-the-moon program know as <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/constellation/main/" target="_blank">Constellation</a>. The Undersecretary of the Air Force - Gary Payton - told a Senate subcommittee retiring the shuttle and canceling Ares 1 may force Pratt and Witney to double the price of its rocket engines - the overhead stays the same - even though the demand decreases. Payton is also concerned the reliability of other space systems - like solar arrays and batteries - may diminish as time goes on.
<!--more--><a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/moon.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2336" title="moon" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/moon.jpg?w=150" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a>Suffice to say the batteries on a long-lost Russian moon rover are now dead - but at least we now know where to find it. NASA's <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/LRO/main/index.html" target="_blank">Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter </a>snapped a picture of the <a href="http://www.aolnews.com/science/article/nasa-photos-reveal-lost-soviet-moon-rover/19405554" target="_blank">Lunokhod 2</a> buggy. A moonstruck astronomy professor Phil Stooke found it when some new LRO images hit the web. The Russians launched the Lunokhod - which means moon walker -  in 1973 - drove it around for four months - before it got stuck in a crater. No one was sure exactly where it was. Lunokhod is owned by Richard Garriott - son of Skylab astronaut Owen Garriott - and a computer game creator worth millions. He bought himself a trip on a Soyuz to the space station in 2008. Twelve years ago he bought Lunokhod at auction for 68,500 dollars - shipping and handling not included.

Listen up all you blue-suited white-scarved mach 25 flyboys and girls - if you are looking for work and I know many of you are these days - you may want to consider this - <a href="http://www.bigelowaerospace.com/" target="_blank">Bigelow Aerospace</a> - the company that is building inflatable orbiting satellites that founder Robert Bigelow would like to one day run as hotels - is looking to hire you. The astronaut positions are permanent - and applicants must have completed a government space training program - and have some space flight experience. The times are changing in Low Earth Orbit.

<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/enterprise.jpg"><img class="alignright size-thumbnail wp-image-2337" title="enterprise" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/enterprise.jpg?w=150" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a>The<a href="http://www.nasm.si.edu/collections/artifact.cfm?id=A19860004000" target="_blank"> Enterprise</a> never made it to low earth orbit - it was designed to test the flying characteristics of a space shuttle orbiter - and today it sits in the Air and Space Museum's Udvar Hazy facility at Dulles Airport. But not for long - an eleven member team from shuttle prime contractor United Space Alliance went to the museum to make sure Enterprise could be cleared for flight to a museum yet to be named. After Discovery flies her last flight, she will take Enterprise's spot. Shuttle curator Valeri Neal told <a href="http://www.collectspace.com">CollectSpace</a> there were no show stoppers.

<a href="http://www.theharrisfoundation.org/index.htm" target="_blank">Bernard Harris</a> is the kind of person who doesn't let show stoppers get in the way of his mission. The retired astronaut, physician and businessman is now working hard to inspire young people to embrace technical fields. I spoke with Bernard a few weeks ago.

<!--more-->

[caption id="attachment_2264" align="alignright" width="150" caption="&quot;Blue Marble&quot; Source:  NASA"]<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/03/bluemarble.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-2264" title="bluemarble" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpgmilesobrien/files/2010/03/bluemarble-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a>[/caption]

Our little planet is just brimming with life - and in fact scientists are no longer surprised to find living things under just about every frozen rock - or deep beneath the sea. But this one caught them off guard - You are looking at <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/topics/earth/features/antarctic-shrimp.html" target="_blank">shrimp</a> that live at a depth of 600 feet - below the Antarctic ice sheet. A NASA/National Science Foundation expedition led by Bob Bindschadler made the amazing find in November. The team expected to find...well...shrimpier forms of life - you know, microbes...the fact that shrimp live here has stumped them - they're not sure what they eat. But it does make you wonder what might be under the ice sheet of Jupiter's moon Europa...doesn't it? So why aren't we sending a mission there? Just asking...and if we go - I guess we should pack some cocktail sauce.

<a href="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2339" title="helicopter" src="http://milesobrien.files.wordpress.com/2010/03/helicopter.jpg?w=150" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a>And we end with more proof there is nothing more fun that watching things crash - so long as its just a few dummies that bear the brunt of the impact. The place is NASA's Langley Research Center in Virginia -the object: to test a Kevlar honeycomb cushion that might save lives in a chopper crash. In December - they tried a 35 foot drop with the cushion.
We are told this one was survivable. But the other day - <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/topics/aeronautics/features/helodrop-mar2010.html" target="_blank">they did the same test </a>- without the cushion - same chopper - same dummies - same sensors. There was a lot more damage - and the dummies took a 40 G wallop - three times the impact on the first test.  Not good for the dummies - but for the smarties who dreamed up the kevlar cushion: a good day indeed. So kids - study hard - you don't wanna grow up to be a dummy.
<div class="zemanta-pixie"><img class="zemanta-pixie-img" src="http://img.zemanta.com/pixy.gif?x-id=b7903bd3-665d-4dd6-8796-32cdd726f29c" alt="" /><span class="zem-script pretty-attribution more-related"> </span></div>]]></content:encoded>
